entry.title: Master
entry.content:
Since last Wednesday (June 25, 2008) I am Master Of Science (MSc) in Computer Science also known as Mestrado em Engenharia InformÃ¡tica in Portuguese. An "old school" MSc by the way, since it is a pre-Bologna Master degree.

The story (thus far)

Well, part of story was already told in my previous post, but there's always a couple of things unsaid. The thesis started in October 2006, after a talk with Ana Moreira and Pedro Guerreiro. During the first semester I did a huge work on research and development, and in the second semester I did my last two courses required for the degree (I needed six, but four of them I have done them already in my Bachelor degree as optional courses). Shortly after that (June 2007) my scholarship ended and I started working as a software developer, which meant that my thesis dissertation went into a hiatus. Only in October 2007 did I gathered the courage to return to the dissertation, by claiming Friday as my "academic" day. Finally, in February of this way, I finished the dissertation, and after a couple of unrelated issues (namely, one my supervisors moved to another university and the other one got sick) I have presented it.

Presentation

Well, I was a little nervous with the presentation (as always) but it went pretty well. My jury included Luis Monteiro, Pedro Guerreiro, JoÃ£o AraÃºjo, and JoÃ£o Fernandes from Universidade do Minho. I got a grade of Muito Bom por unanimidade (an unanimous "Very Good"), which is pretty good grade. But more importantly, I got some nice complements about my work.

So, what is your thesis about, anyway?

Well, a lot of people ask me this question, and I usually avoid it. Why? Well, when you work on a subject for a long time, sometimes you get a little sick from grokking your thesis. Worst, in all thesis you examine a subject so closely, that even other researchers and professionals in your area really don't understand you. So, you get a little annoyed with the question. Anyway, I must overcome this, so were is the answer.
In my thesis, I explored how to extend a programming language (namely Java) with full support for the Design by Contract approach, using Aspect-Oriented Programming technologies. My AOP background came from my BSc, but my DbC interest came a long way...

Design by Contract

While reviewing my BSc projects I found a report from a (somewhere between 2005 and 2006) project in an Algorithms and Data Structures course were I used a light Object-Oriented approach for writing C code (!), which DbC in the form of comments. But as I looked a little closer, the idea of DbC was already in my head before that when I learned Object Constraint Language (OCL). Interestingly, I learned UML in a System Analysis course, taught by Ana Moreira, one of my future supervisors. However, a couple of weeks ago I was re-reading the introduction of my first computer science book (an Object-Oriented C++ book), I found out that author had a great interest in DbC, which he through out the book. Well, it happens that the book was ProgramaÃ§Ã£o com Classes em C++, which was written by none other than Pedro Guerreiro, my first programming teacher at the university, and my other future supervisor! So, in a certain way, the circle is completed.

Is it over?

This was one of the questions posed by some people and the Master thesis jury. (Which means: "Are you going to do a PhD?"). Well, one thing I have learned: never say never. Having said that, my answer is no, I'm not going to do a PhD, at least not in the foreseeable future of the next couple of years. I have been in the academic world for about nine years, and I really need to do some "out of the box" thinking/working. Also, I need to work on my social skills which includes some non-functional requirements :) But, if a good opportunity comes along, an opportunity which is compatible with my industry career and does not involve over-working, I might consider doing another degree and/or teaching (which is something I have been curious about for some time).
Meanwhile, I have to finished the revised version of my master thesis, as well as finishing some paper work. Also, I got an invitation to write extended versions of two of published research papers, which I am considering. Anyway, after that it is very likely that my connection to the academic world will be more sporadic. After all, I have to invest on my software developer career, which happens to be my paying job!

Until next time, may you enjoy reaching a step further.

entry.title: An Aspect for Design by Contract in Java @ICEIS 2008
entry.content:
Last week, I attended the 10th International Conference on Enterprise Information Systems, also known as ICEIS 2008, in Barcelona, Spain. During my stay there I presented three research papers, which I am going to write about it in (at least) three posts.

The first paper I presented was "An Aspect for Design by Contract in Java", co-authored by Dr. Pedro Guerreiro and Hugo Taborda. This paper was presented at satellite event, the 6th International Workshop on Modelling, Simulation, Verification and Validation of Enterprise Information Systems, also known as MSVVEIS 2008. This paper corresponds to the core of my master thesis dissertation, and has a long story, which began even before my Master Thesis.

Pedro Guerreiro is a lecturer and researcher that for many years has been interested in Design by Contract, which he learnt through the Eiffel programming language. Since then, he has work on ad-hoc support for DbC in C++. With the advent of Aspect-Oriented Programming he imaged that it could be used to implement DbC support in more clean way. And so a master thesis began... with Hugo Taborda. For some time Hugo worked on this theme, but due to reasons outside of the scope of this blog, he diverted from this to other projects, and the thesis entered in a hiatus.

Fast forward to October 2006. I had just finished my Bachelor degree, had a research background in Aspect-Oriented Software Development with requirements engineering and had just decided to start a Master degree in a more implementation focused theme. It wasn't long until I "stole" the Master thesis. As the Thesis unfolded, it wasn't long until we started thinking on writing a paper. And thus a struggle began.

When we first started writing the paper, my thesis was still not in its final form, but we wanted to give it go, even if it was only for feedback purposes. Unfortunately, the research community wasn't very fond of the idea, and the paper was submitted and rejected in several conferences over the following months. I can't really remember all of them, but it was rejected in the three communities which may have an interest on it: Java (PPPJ), Object-Oriented (TOOLS), and Aspect-Oriented (AOSD). It was a hard road, but it provided a lot of feedback for the thesis, as well as teaching me endurance.

So, I finally got the paper accepted, and presented it last Friday, the 13th (not a good premise!). Anyway, the presentation went really well, at least for my standards, since I get really nervous doing presentations. Unfortunately, the attendance was not that big, and most of the researchers at the workshop where not really interested in this research stream.

Until next time, may you enjoy finishing an old objective.

entry.title: The Avengers?
entry.content:
If you recently went to cinema to watch the Iron Man (2008) movie, and stayed until the end, there was a nice easter egg where Nick Fury proposed Tony Stark to join the Avengers. (If not, you can see it here.) If you are a former comic book geek (such as I), then you must wondering... that would be cool, but is it feasible? You would need to have a lot of movies just to introduce the characters...
Well, I did a little search by IMDB, and guess what did I found out:
  • The Incredible Hulk (2008)
  • Thor (2010)
  • Sub-Mariner (2010)
  • The First Avenger: Captain America (2011)
And last, but not least:
  • The Avengers (2011)
Not so crazy after all! Well, the movies listed make up the original line-up of the team (well, except Wasp and Ant-man, but who knows...). Anyway, there are other Avenger characters in existing movies of the Marvel franchise, such as Spider-man, X-Men and the Fantastic Four.

Until next time, may you enjoy the return of your former heroes.

entry.title: Hyper/Net: MDSoC support for .NET
entry.content:
Earlier this year, I attended the MSc discussion of Tiago Dias, entitled "Hyper/Net: MDSoC support for .NET". The thesis explored Multi-Dimensional Separation of Concerns (MDSoc) for the .NET platform, namely using the C# programming language. The idea is based Hyper/J, a research project abandoned by IBM a couple of years ago. While this may same like a bad start, Tiago's presentation was very good and convincing. Essentially, the MDSoC support is based on .NET's partial classes and some generative programming techniques. This work originated a research paper, with the same name of the dissertation, published in 2006. Also, some of the dissertation's chapters were stripped, as they belong on a possible future PhD thesis. These chapters dealt with the cognitive aspects of the multidimensional separation of concerns.

Until next time, may you enjoy separating concerns, one way or the other.

entry.title: Esperteza Saloia
entry.content:
Hoje vou escrever um pouco sobre um assunto que jÃ¡ hÃ¡ muito gostava de escrever, mas que devido Ã  sua complexidade, o tenho evitado fazer: a chamada "pirataria". Neste post, vou falar um pouco sobre um tipo de pirataria em particular, a de software.

MotivaÃ§Ã£o

HÃ¡ alguns anos atrÃ¡s, numa aula do Prof. Pedro Guerreiro, ele falava sobre o facto de muitos alunos copiarem ilegalmente software, sem terem uma real necessidade. Na altura chamou-lhe "esperteza saloia". Hoje, um amigo com que falava no MSN, perguntava-me que versÃ£o do Visual Studio precisaria para um projecto escolar. Para as necessidades que ele me perguntou, eu recomendei-lhe o Visual Studio 2005 Express Edition. No entanto, ele preferiu "sacar" uma das versÃµes avanÃ§adas do VS 2008. Ou seja, em vez de fazer o download de uma versÃ£o gratuita e legal de poucas centenas de MiB, preferiu fazer o download de vÃ¡rios CDs de uma versÃ£o pirata. A justificaÃ§Ã£o: "preferia ter uma versÃ£o *completa*".

O Problema

Longe vai o tempo em que as pessoas usavam software ilegal por necessidade. Hoje em dia quase todas as grandes linhas de software comercial tÃªm uma versÃ£o gratuita, seja ela uma ediÃ§Ã£o express, light, ou home. Na pior das hipÃ³teses tÃªm um trial de N dias. Isto jÃ¡ para nÃ£o falar no software freeware e FOSS (no caso do meu amigo, ele ainda tinha a possibilidade de usar o SharpDevelop, uma IDE open-source para .NET). Porque Ã© que entÃ£o se generalizou de tal maneira o uso de software ilegal? Porque Ã© fÃ¡cil. Por ganÃ¢ncia. Sim, a maior parte das vezes Ã© mesmo por ganÃ¢ncia. NÃ£o me venham com histÃ³rias de que a empresa X e Y (tipicamente a Microsoft, um alvo fÃ¡cil) sÃ£o gananciosas e que o software Ã© muito caro. NÃ£o me venham com histÃ³rias de que sÃ£o vitimas do capitalismo (tipicamente americano, outro alvo fÃ¡cil), ou de que sÃ£o "Robins do Bosques". Se existem alternativas e as pessoas nÃ£o as usam, isso para mim Ã© ganÃ¢ncia, pura e simplesmente.

Advogado do Diabo

Sou contra a "pirataria"? Sim, sou. Mas tambÃ©m nÃ£o sou a favor de campanhas de caÃ§a Ã s bruxas, propaganda na comunicaÃ§Ã£o social, ou medidas de protecÃ§Ã£o idiotas. (Na realidade, eu atÃ© acho que Ã© uma questÃ£o de tempo [dÃ©cadas, talvez] atÃ© todo o software se tornar FOSS e o prÃ³prio fenÃ³meno de pirataria deixar de existir como o conhecemos hoje, mas isso Ã© uma histÃ³ria para outra altura.) O prÃ³prio termo "pirataria" Ã© em si uma termo enviesado e errado (ver prÃ³ximo parÃ¡grafo).
As campanhas que se tÃªm feito em Portugal sobre pirataria (em geral, nÃ£o sÃ³ sobre software) comparam a cÃ³pia legal de software ao roubo de carros e carteira. Isso para mim Ã© propaganda pura. A cÃ³pia ilegal de software Ã©, passe a expressÃ£o, ilegal, nÃ£o "um crime". (A venda desse mesmo software, apesar de na minha opiniÃ£o abominÃ¡vel, continua a ser ilegal, nÃ£o propriamente um crime).
NÃ£o sou a favor das licenÃ§as abusivas e validaÃ§Ãµes draconianas. TambÃ©m nÃ£o sou a favor das protecÃ§Ãµes contra cÃ³pia que existe em muito software, especialmente jogos, nomeadamente porque prejudicam mais as pessoas que compram de facto o software, que os restantes. Como exemplo, um amigo meu emprestou-me um jogo que ele tinha comprado. Como era aborrecido ter constantemente o CD na drive sempre que queria jogar, acabei por ter de pesquisar um "crack" para remover essa protecÃ§Ã£o. Quem Ã© que ficou prejudicado com este mecanismo?

Piratas

Se formos a um dicionÃ¡rio, podemos encontrar algo como o seguinte em pirata:

do Lat. pirata peiratÃ©s

s. 2 gÃ©n.,
aquele que cruza os mares para assaltar e roubar navios;

corsÃ¡rio;

aquele que sequestra e desvia aviÃµes (frequentemente com pretextos polÃ­ticos);

ladrÃ£o;
fig.,
pessoa que enriquece Ã  custa de outrem por meio de exacÃ§Ãµes violentas;

malandro;

velhaco;
prov.,
tratante;
Brasil,
sedutor;

conquistador;
adj. 2 gÃ©n.,
fraudulento;
Inform.,
pessoa que se introduz nos sistemas informÃ¡ticos de outros, passando para alÃ©m de protecÃ§Ãµes e passwords, podendo ou nÃ£o danificÃ¡-los ou utilizÃ¡-los ilicitamente.
Bom, os termos que se referem aos piratas histÃ³ricos sÃ£o abusivos: uma pessoa que usa software ilegal nÃ£o estÃ¡ a roubar, sequestrar ou violentar outro. A ideia de roubar continua a ser o ponto que me incomoda. DÃ¡ a ideia que se estÃ¡ a tirar algo a alguÃ©m sem lhe pagar. Ora, isto dÃ¡ a entender que todas as pessoas que pirateam software o pagariam se nÃ£o tivessem acesso a uma versÃ£o ilegal. Isto estÃ¡ muito longe da verdade. Muito do software pirateado nÃ£o seria adquirido noutras circunstÃ¢ncias, porque a maior parte das pessoas arranjariam alternativas gratuitas. Ou simplesmente as pessoas nÃ£o usariam de todo o software em causa, porque na minha opiniÃ£o muitas das vezes nÃ£o existe uma necessidade real do software.
A definiÃ§Ã£o aplicada Ã  informÃ¡tica confunde o acesso a um sistema com o uso ilegal de software, misturando hacking com piraria. NÃ£o vamos por aÃ­! Isso Ã© outra conversa...

Hipocrisia

Ã Ã³bvio que jÃ¡ pirateei software. Muito atÃ©. Especialmente jogos. Em retrospectiva, o tempo que passei a arranjar centenas de jogos, podiam ter sido mais bem aproveitados a comprar e jogar a meia dÃºzia que realmente joguei. Hoje em dia sou contra o acto de piratear um software, especialmente quando nÃ£o existe uma real necessidade. Creio que neste momento o Ãºnico software que tenho ilegal Ã© o Windows 2000 no meu PC Desktop (AKA "Tarja"). A Ãºnica coisa que posso dizer em minha defesa Ã© que se trata de um PC velho que adquiri em segunda mÃ£o (sem sistema operativo), e que nÃ£o se justifica nesta altura adquirir um SO para um PC com tempo de vida reduzido, ainda mais porque o software em causa jÃ¡ nÃ£o Ã© comercializado pela Microsoft (bom, o abandonware Ã© ainda outra histÃ³ria para mais um dia...). Continua a ser errado, no entanto.

AtÃ© Ã  prÃ³xima, que apreciem ter a coragem de questionar comportamentos generalizados.

entry.title: My Trip to Brussels
entry.content:
As I told in a previous post, last week I was at Brussels. I am going to write a little bit about my trip and stay there.

The Plane

One of the cool stuff of this trip was that I got to do my first plane trip. Also, I got to go in the window seat! The plane is much smaller than I imagined (then again, the Lisbon-Brussels flight isn't exactly the most used flight), as well as noisier. Although I didn't have any fear of flying, I confess that I was little apprehensive during the take-off. Something to mark in my check-list of things I wanted to do in my life time.
I think the airports are very confusing for a first-time user, especially the Brussels airport which is quite huge. Anyway, it all went well, despite the departure's flight was an hour late, at least they didn't lose my luggage.

My plane

No, no gremlin on the wing


Belgium: a new country

Although I have done some trips outside of Portugal, I have only been to Spain and Andorra (well, technically I was in France, but only on an Andorra trip). In general, I liked the country, at least what I have seen - the centre of Brussels. In spite of being the "capital" of the European Union, I didn't feel like a cosmopolitan city: the traffic looked organized, lots of parking places, and lots of green spaces. Most people I interacted with in the city knew how to speak English, in spite of their annoying French accent. Overall, the city was very English-speaking friendly: most of the shops and signs were in English. Oh, and a lot of chocolate :)

Now I know: chocolate comes from fountains!


Tintin, Captain Haddock and Milou in another adventure!

Sightseeing

Let me tell you a secret: I skipped the second day at the conference to do some sightseeing. You live once! And I sure didn't want to skip this change. Since I am not a very cult person (at least in terms of history and geography), I didn't where to go, other than the Belgium Comic Strip Museum. Fortunately, sightseeing maps from the Hotel to the rescue! I got into the subway and went to visit some spots in the map, with a little of walking (which I enjoy to do).
I enjoyed the most were parks and the buildings in general. The Atomium is very impressive, but Manneken Pis is really overrated. Grand Place and in general most of the historical part of the city were very nice.

Europa riding Zeus

Les Arcades du Cinquantenaire

Atomium

Place Des Martirs

Tintin's Moon rocket @ Brussels Comic Strip Museum

Until next time, may you enjoy travelling whenever you have the opportunity.

entry.title: Contracts for Aspect-Oriented Design @ AOSD.08
entry.content:
This week I was at the AOSD.08 conference, in Brussels, Belgium. There I presented a research paper, "Contracts for Aspect-Oriented Design".

AOSD.08

The path into AOSD.08


The international conference on Aspect-Oriented Software Development (AKA: AOSD) in the most important conference for Aspect-Oriented Software Development. This year's edition, the seventh, was hosted in the "heart" of Europe, Brussels. The activities were from March 31st to April 4th, and included: the research track, where the latest and most important research papers are presented; the industry track, where the papers on the latest developments in the industry are presented; the workshops, where specific subjects are treated through paper presentation and group discussion; the tutorials, where a person or a group of persons will be presenting and lecturing about a specific theme; and student extravaganza, where MSc or PhD students present posters on their theses' development. There is also space for some tool demonstrations and some social events.
During my short stay at the conference (only the first two days of the week), I stumbled upon some fellow researchers which I have met in GTTSE and SWERC 2007, as well as several Portuguese people. I also got to talk with Dean Wampler, an interesting industry consultant and researcher, whose work has influenced my paper, and in general my master thesis.

SLAT Workshop

Group discussion @ SPLAT

I participated in the Software-engineering Properties of Languages and Aspect Technologies (SPLAT) workshop. In this 6th edition, the theme was discussing how does Aspect-Oriented Programming (AOP) cope with good software engineering properties (e.g. reliability, testability, etc.). This was very interesting, because although my current research is on programming and design, the 'illities' are essentially non-functional requirements, which links with my previous research work on requirements engineering. My paper was generally well accepted, although my actual presentation was less than impressive (I still get nervous when making presentations). In summary, it was actually constructive, as I got some positive comments and some new ideas on issues that I should have addressed or at least considered.

Contracts for Aspect-Oriented Design

The paper presentation's cover slide

The story of this paper started about a year ago. At the time, I was still about half-way through my master thesis, as well as doing my final two courses needed for the master degree. One of such courses was TÃ³picos AvanÃ§ados em Engenharia de Software (Advanced Topics on Software Engineering), lectured by one my supervisors, Ana Moreira. There, I was suppose to make a paper assignment, which could be a first draft of a chapter of my upcoming dissertation. While helpful, I was getting a little bored of just my thesis, and wanted to think a little "outside of the box". The paper was born, with the exact same title as today.
Since both my supervisors liked it, we later decided to expand and improve it a little, in order to make a extra chapter on my dissertation. Chapter 7 was born :) It wasn't much later than we concluded that with a little work, we could make conference worthy. And so, when working in a paper which represented the core of my thesis, we decided to also make a paper out it, and submitted both to the AOSD conference. Interestingly, my master thesis "core" paper was rejected (once again, but that is a story for another post...), while my master thesis "spin-off" paper was accepted.

Until next time, may you enjoy doing a little of out of the box thinking.

entry.title: SPLAT @ AOSD.08: paper available
entry.content:
The paper "Contracts for Aspect-Oriented Design", co-authored by me, Pedro Guerreiro, and Ana Moreira is available. I will present this paper March 31 of this year, in the SPLAT workshop at AOSD.08, located in Brussels, Belgium. The document is available for download, as well as the schedule.

Splash... or should I say splat?


This paper was developed in the context of my Master Thesis, and the co-authors are my supervisors. It is going to be an interesting experience, as I've never been to a research conference before. Anyway, I can already see some interesting names in this workshop, such as Miguel Monteiro, a fellow researcher at CITI; and Krzysztof Czarnecki, the "father" of generative programming, whom I've met last summer. Hopefully, I'll meet some more people from the main conference or other workshops.


Until next time, may you enjoy presenting your work.

entry.title: ... still an academic...
entry.content:
In spite of my new job, I am still connected to FCT.

Current papers and conferences

Recently, two of my research papers where accepted at two conferences, where I will be presenting them. My work at CITI in the context of SOFTAS project and my master thesis, was accepted at a workshop in the AOSD 2008. My work at CA3 in the context of the ASSD project and my bachelor degree was accepted at ICEIS 2008. AOSD is coming up at the end of this month in Bruxels, Belgium; while ICEIS comes later, by the middle of June, in Barcelona, Spain. When I have more time to blog, I will write a post on both of these papers, as they all have interesting stories.

Upcoming papers

Still, my work is not done, I am involved in three other papers. A paper on the ASSD project is submitted to a Journal, and is under a revision process. Two more papers related to my master thesis are under development, and may or may not be submitted in a near future. Yeah, one of them also has an interesting story.

My master thesis

Yes, somewhere in between the writing/revising process of research papers, I have a master thesis dissertation a couple of months late. This will definitively be worth a couple of blog posts. Hopefully, it will be discussed in a month or two.

When will the madness end?

I don't know, but somewhere this year I must end my connection to the university. Having a double life of developer by day, and researcher by night, is somewhat stressful and exhausting. I am going to need some more space for my personal and social life.

Until next time, may you enjoy doing a lot of stuff... even tough sometimes you are not sure for what purpose...

entry.title: ... Hello ViaTecla
entry.content:
Since February 2, 2008, I am working at ViaTecla Software as a Software Developer.


ViaTecla

ViaTecla is medium sized company in the software industry, located near Almada. It is composed into three divisions: Software (internal development), Operations (technical maintenance), and Projects (out sourcing).Its core business areas are in the tourism (KEYforTravel product) and web site content management (ScriptorServer product). VT is a Microsoft Gold Partner, and as such I believe it is my duty to always carry my Java PT 07 satchel, as well as my Java/Sun umbrella ;)

My Job

As said, I am software developer in the software division, the largest. While I am not working in any of the main products' teams, most of the projects where I work are based on them. Although I cannot disclose much detail about my work (damn NDAs :)), I can say that I'm working in the development of new projects and products, in multimedia technologies. These involve Microsoft's state of the art: .NET 3.5, Silverlight, Windows Media Services, etc. While I don't have a strong background in the multimedia area, I consider myself a good software engineer, and good engineering is always useful, whatever the software development area is.

Until next time, may enjoy having the courage of taking new challenges and risks.

entry.title: Farewell ISIS...
entry.content:
January 31, 2008 was my last day working at ISIS.


ISIS

ISIS (Intelligent Sensorial Information Systems) is a spin-off of the CA3 (now know as Computational Intelligence Research Group) at UNINOVA. I have been working there since last June, in the "SGF" project. It is a research/industry project, namely a management system, based on .NET 2.0 technology. Due to an informal NDA, if I told you more about this then I would have to kill you :)

The ISIS team

During my stay here, I had the joy of meeting a nice group of people, both professionally as personally. Namely:

JosÃ© Manuel Fonseca, holds a BSc in Computer Science, a MSc in Computer Science, and a PhD in Electrotechnical Engineering. Currently he is a professor at the Electrotechnical Department at the university. He is definitely the best "boss" I ever had, with a very good sense of humour, and a very good speaker, he always has an interesting talk to do.

AndrÃ© Mora, holds a BSc in Electrotechnical Engineering, and a MSc in Computer Science. Currently he is lecturing at the Electrotechnical Departament, as well as finishing his PhD. AndrÃ© is a natural leader, always available to solve the tough problems and arguments.

InÃªs Guerra, holds a BSc in Electrotechnical Engineering. After a brief experience in consulting and international lecturing, she decided to return to the university on an entrepreneurship journey. She is the "glue" of the team, always promoting dialogue among the team, as well as finding (as sometimes solving) the various non-functional issues associated with software development.

Fernando Moitinho, holds a BSc in Electrotechnical Engineering. Currently he is assistant at the Electrotechnical Department, as well as finishing his MSc in the "spare" time. Fernando is a hard-working person, the most productive member in terms LOC per hour :)

Catarina Gomes, is taking a BSc in Computer Science. She is no longer a current member of the team, but working as a research engineer at CA3. Catarina was the most "crosscutting" member, always available to perform the scattered tasks that no one else could do.

Sofia Moura, is taking a degree in design and multimedia. Sofia was the official graphical designer, that is, the person that made everything look pretty.

Carlos Figueira, holds a BSc in Electrotechnical Engineering. Carlos is the hardware guy, as well as the "holy" sysadmin. Need I say more?

Ana Fachada, holds a BSc in Electrotechnical Engineering. After working in consulting, she is currently developing her PhD. Since she is the most recent "acquisition" of the group, but an interesting one, since she has a pragmatic view in the "business" perspective of software development.

There would be a lot more to say about these people and this project, a lot more than a blog post would do justice. For a couple of months, all of use gave all they've got into this project, and for that we shared a bond. This was the best team I have worked with, and I wish them the best of luck in the future.

InÃªs Guerra, Fernando Moitinho, AndrÃ© Mora, JosÃ© Manuel Fonseca and me
(October 13, an important milestone in the project)

Next

More than a goodbye from ISIS, this is a goodbye from FCT, because since then I start a new job, in the so-called (software) industry. But that is another story...

Until next time, may you enjoy being able to let go the people and places you care about, even when it is not easy.

entry.title: caleb.pt.vu - v42.1
entry.content:
Yesterday I've updated my personal static web site.

new look


old look

What's new

So, what's new? Actually, nothing. No new content, just a new look. My Web site is now literally a single XHTML page (although some images and CSS are external, an interesting exercise would putting it all into a single file). That's it. The idea is to simply have all my static content into a single page. Simple, fast and maintainable. All the rest is already done by someone else, and typically better.

Join the dark side

Regarding the darker look, I have to admit to have been influenced by the Blackle web site, as well as the dark skins of Microsoft's Office 2007 and Expression Studio (which in itself is a post of its own). I think it looks pretty cool and elegant, although I may have to review some of the text colours, in order to improve some of the contrast.

Coming soon

Once again I have a backlog of blog posts to write, but I'm not sure when am I going to have the time and patience to catch up. So much to do and so little time...

Until next time, may you enjoy making simple things.

entry.title: A new (e)buddy
entry.content:
Need to use a chat service, but you don't enough permissions in the computer, or your network is under a proxy? Try ebuddy. It runs a couple of protocols (namely MSN, Google Talk, Yahoo, AIM, and MySpace), provides a good set of features, and runs relatively smoothly through the use of AJAX. Its like Pidgin, in the sense that you can mix all networks in a single contact tree, but web based.
Of course, its not perfect. You can't log your conversations (if you're paranoid like me, you usually do that), for technical/security reasons. You can't send or receive files. And of course, you can't use the most advance features, such as web cam, window skinning, etc., which, since I'm used to third-party clients such aMSN and GAIM/Pidgin, - heck, I've even used JMSN a couple of years ago, is not a big loss. Anyway, life is made of compromises, and this is one of them :)

Until next time, may you enjoy finding a new (e)buddy.

entry.title: SQL Server BCP
entry.content:
A couple of weeks ago I was writing a small application to perform some ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) operations. As I was researching an efficient way to perform a large number of SQL insert statements, I found out about the BCP (Bulk CoPy) utility for MS SQL Server. This tool performs efficient data insertion (something in the order of thousands of row inserts per second), using as source CSV (Comma Separated Values) files. The mapping is performed through configuration files in a semi-structured format, or using an XML file (the latter is strongly recommended). Basically, the trick resides that unlike in regular inserts, database restrictions (primary keys, foreign keys, unique restrictions, null values, etc.) are not enforced for each row, but only at the end of the introduction, or per each block.

This was good solution for my needs at the time, which was to extract a large number of data from CSV files into a small number of tables, on a secondary database to the system in question. Of course, the mapping is limited: you cannot perform data normalization, only insert/remove columns, or switch its order. This means that either the input data is normalized, or you end up with a denormalized database. In sum, BCP does not replace an ETL tool, but provides an interesting complement in the "Loading" part.

By the way, a very nice book on the subject is Professional SQL Server 2005 Programming, by Robert Vieira, published by Wrox.



Until next time, may you enjoy bulk copying.

entry.title: The Rough Guide to Horror Movies
entry.content:
"The Rough Guide to Horror Movies", is book by Alan Jones, which was offered to me as a gift last Christmas. This is a guide to horror movies (of which I'm a big fan). As such, one of my purposes for this year is to see every movie in the list (50).



The List
  1. An American Werewolf in London (1981)
  2. Black Sunday (1977)
  3. OK Braindead (1992)
  4. Bride of Frankenstein (1935)
  5. Cabinet des Dr. Caligari., Das (1920)
  6. Cannibal Holocaust (1980)
  7. Carrie (1976)
  8. The Cat and the Canary (1927)
  9. Cat People (1942)
  10. The Curse of Frankenstein (1957)
  11. OK Dawn of the Dead (1978)
  12. Diaboliques, Les (1955)
  13. Dracula (1931)
  14. Dracula (1958)
  15. OK The Evil Dead (1981)
  16. OK The Exorcist (1973)
  17. Yeux sans visage, Les (1960)
  18. Frankenstein (1931)
  19. Freaks (1932)
  20. Halloween (1978)
  21. The Haunting (1963/I)
  22. The Innocents (1961)
  23. I Walked with a Zombie (1943)
  24. OK Jaws (1975)
  25. Near Dark (1987)
  26. OK A Nightmare on Elm Street (1984)
  27. Night of the Demon (1957)
  28. OK Night of the Living Dead (1968)
  29. Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens (1922)
  30. The Old Dark House (1932)
  31. Onibaba (1964)
  32. Peeping Tom (1960)
  33. The Phantom of the Opera (1925)
  34. Pit and the Pendulum (1961)
  35. The Plague of the Zombies (1966)
  36. Psycho (1960)
  37. Re-Animator (1985)
  38. Repulsion (1965)
  39. Ringu (1998)
  40. Rosemary's Baby (1968)
  41. Scream (1996/I)
  42. The Shining (1980)
  43. Shivers (1975)
  44. OK The Silence of the Lambs (1991)
  45. The Sixth Sense (1999)
  46. Suspiria (1977)
  47. Haute tension (2003)
  48. The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)
  49. The Uninvited (1944)
  50. Witchfinder General (1968)
(Note that I've used the original titles and dates, according to IMDB, and not by the book.)

What I have saw

Since I am big fan of zombie films, especially from George Romero, it is no surprise that I've seen those. Anthony Hopkins role of Hannibal Hecter is a pretty good one, so the Hannibal series are a classic. Sharks and exorcisms are also a classic!

What I would like to see

The Phantom of the Opera, Psycho, The Shining, The Texas Chain Saw Massacre are cult movies that I have been waiting for a change to see for a while. Ringu and The Sixth Sense are two modern movies that people have talking about, and I am a little curious.

What I think should be in the list

While I haven't read the book yet, looking at list I think it should be a little broader in scope. Sci-fi movies such as Alien (1979), The Terminator (1984) or Predator (1987) shouldn't be excluded from the list. It also came as a surprise to me that Freddy Kruger is not accompanied by Jason Voorhees or Chucky! Also, some recent movies should have made it to the cut: Se7en (1995), The Blair Witch Project (1999), Saw (2004), Hostel (2005). Finally, vampire movies such as Dracula (1992) and Interview with the Vampire: The Vampire Chronicles (1994) are the best vampire movies I have saw.

My task

Has seen on the list, I only saw 8 of the 50 movies. 42 horror movies to see in a year! I'll be posting some comments on this blog entry as I am going through them, so be sure to check it out from time to time.

Until next time, may you enjoy being afraid... being very afraid... muauahahahahahaha!

entry.title: AGM MSc thesis web site

entry.title: Yoga (101 Essential Tips)
entry.content:
Last year, I bought a nice little book called "Yoga (101 Essential Tips)".


Yes, it looks like a "supermarket book" (actually, a lot of books from this publisher are available at supermarkets), but its a good place to start, especially if you are new to Yoga and don't feel like doing a big investment in books, at least right away. The book is very direct and summarizes the basics of a good number of asanas, talks a little bit about pranayma, and provides some ideas on food (from the Yoga point of view), as well as couple of general tips. While not a complete book, its a good reference for the beginner, it's small, and it's cheap (a little more than â¬5 for the Portuguese print).

Until next time, may you enjoy finding the little things in life that matter.

entry.title: Europass CV
entry.content:
Lately, some people have (willingly or not!) requested my opinion on their CVs. My first recommendation is to use the Europass template.


Euro-who?

The europass is an initiative that aims to promote job "interoperability" among European countries, which includes a set of templates for job related documents, including the CV (Curriculum Vitae). Having a standard CV template is an advantage for those who are looking for a job, and the employer. The CV template, instructions and examples are available for download in MS Word and OpenDocument formats (yeah!) for several languages.
As with any CV, my second advice is to change specific parts of the template whenever you feel like it could be improved. Also, try not to make a CV that is either too small or too big: 2-4 pages is the recommended size.

Until next time, may you enjoy looking for a job.

entry.title: Garbage-collecting 2007
entry.content:
Maintaining a blog gives me the opportunity to write about a lot of subjects. Unfortunately, I don't have as much time and patience as I would like to, and so a lot of draft posts get postponed indefinitely. As we come to the end of 2007, I've choose to "garbage collect" all these lost posts, in a quick review.

Five Years of Magic

2007 was my fifth year playing Magic: the Gathering. However, I have since decided to abandon the game (whether I will return to it or not, is an open question). Anyway, there are a lot of things to be said beyond the game itself, which pretty interesting: the colour philosophy, the art, the storyline, the tournaments, and the human interaction aspect of the game. Magic is not just a game, it is a way of living. Hopefully, I will still the time to write about these topics in the future.

A Metadata-Driven Approach for Aspect-Oriented Requirements Analysis

This is the name of a paper I have been working on since 2006, based on the research work I have done during my BSc project. After two rejections and revisions, last August it was finally accepted in an international conference, but due to the lack of financing from the supporting institutions, it was not possible to send any of the authors to attend the conference (which means that the paper was not published). Since then, the paper has been re-submitted to another conference and it is currently under evaluation.

JavaPT07

This was industry event held in last September at my university, sponsored by Sun Microsystems, as a side event of the PPPJ 2007 - Principles and Practices of Programming in Java conference. My initial plan was to attend the actual conference, since I submitted a paper based on the research developed during my MSc thesis. As the paper was rejected, I attended the free industry event. The lectures included:
  • "Open Source Java from Sun", an interesting explanation on Sun's position on FOSS.
  • "What's new on NetBeans 5.5, what's next for NetBeans 6", a quick view on the current and upcoming releases of Sun's IDE. While many of the new features are already present in Eclipse, Sun is making a real effort catching up with them.
  • "JavaFX", a new Java platform language, for multimedia content. It looks like Sun's attempt to battle Microsoft's Silverlight (which in itself is fighting Adobe's Flash technology). Anyway, it interesting to notice that finally Sun is doing some investment into new languages for the Java platform.
  • "OpenSolaris", Sun's shameless advertising of its operating system. Seems like a solid Os, but the truth is I never had any real contact with it. Well, once I ported a small benchmark application from Solaris to Linux, but that was it. It is interesting that Sun garantees that version 10 of their operating system is compatible with every application running from version 2 upwards.
  • "Sun SPOT in Action: 3-D, Virtual Reality and Gaming", an alternative use of Java technology: hardware controller. So, if you are a hardware geek, I should get a perk of this stuff.
SD cards and adhesive tape

Have a problem writing to an SD card on on a specific computer? Well, I did. For several hours I desperately tried to write data into my SD cards with my laptop card reader and nothing. Otherwise the SD cards worked pretty well in digital cameras and GPS systems, but not on my laptop. After installing and re-installing a couple of drivers for Linux and Windows, I broadened my web search and found out that this is an actual recurring problem with computer card readers. The solution: put adhesive tape on your SD card over the write protect switch. It works, believe me.

IronPython and Dynamic Languages Runtime on .NET

This was an (unexpectedly) interesting lecture given by a Microsoft developer. IronPython is Microsoft's implementation of the Python scripting language for the .Net platform. This is achieved through the DLR - Dynamic Language Runtime, a new abstraction layer providing connection to the CLR - Common Language Runtime. So, basically, you can mix IronPython, IronRuby (the MS implementation of Ruby), JScript (the MS implementation of JavaScript), Visual Basic, with Silverlight, ASP.Net and the .Net framework libraries. That's pretty cool. I saw the demo (using .Net 3.0) and it was pretty straightforward. It is interesting to notice that IronPython, as well as the remaining IronSomething language implementations, are open-source (I had to laugh at that point of the lecture), though using a Microsoft license, instead of the usual GPL, BSD, Apache, etc. In summary, the first part of the lecture was about the IronPython, while the second part was on the DLR technology itself.

C# 3.0

With the coming of version 3.0 of the C# language, Microsoft really raised the bar: lambda functions, lazy evaluation, DSL-like features... I'm impressed. According to the blog entry, Microsft's merged some features from experimental language extensions of C# with the main language. Humm, I wonder if they are planning merging Spec# as well (a C# extension for Design by Contract, check out my thesis dissertation in a couple of months)? Sun Microsystems will really have to work hard if they want to keep up with C# and the .Net platform.

Coming up in 2008

The conclusion of my master thesis, my experience with OpenOffice.org Writer 2.0, a little experiment with OOo Base 2.3, the project I have been working on for the last months, and my upcoming job. That, and hopefully much more.

Until next time, may you enjoy cleaning up the house.

entry.title: Vittorio The Vampire
entry.content:
I have just finished reading "Vittorio The Vampire", the second and last book from the "New Tales Of The Vampires" collection, from Anne Rice.


Here be spoilers

In this book, Vittorio, the main character tells his tale. Vittorio is an Italian noble, born in the Renaissance. After his family being murdered by a group of vampires, he sets on quest for vengeance, which leads him to fall in love with one them, Ursula. After being captured and tortured, he is abandoned as insane and is greeted by some guardian angels, who tell him that he must slay all of those vampires...

My tale

Unlike the previous tale ("Pandora"), this book actually lives to its premise of a new tale, which is not related to the vampire chronicles' characters. In terms of Rice's universe, we are presented with the first appearance of angels (well, except for Memnoch), which are oblivious to God's reasoning, as one might expect from her previous books. We are also presented with a new vampire skill (which is unique in Vittorio), the ability to "see" human souls. The character itself, Vittorio, is an interesting one, since he is divided between faith and love. The "Ruby Grail" coven is also an interesting group, similar to Armand's coven in Paris, but where the cult of Lucifer is taken to a higher level, as well as more organized group.
On an on, while not one of the best of Anne Rice's books, it was certainly a interesting departure from the main storyline.

Until next time, may you enjoy a really new tale, from a vampire.

entry.title: Free StarOffice @ Google Pack
entry.content:
A friend of mine has recently called to my attention that StarOffice is now available free of charge, as part of the Google Pack.

What is StarOffice?



StarOffice is an office suite, similar to MS Office. Its the proprietary version of OpenOffice.org, developed by Sun Microsystems (as a side note, originally OpenOffice.org was a spin-off of StarOffice; times have changed). If you already know OOo, then you'll notice the resemblance. In simple terms, StarOffice is a snapshot of OOo, with some extra proprietary features and fonts (although, as another interesting side note, internalization support is smaller in StarOffice). StarOffice is a commercial alternative to MS Office, for companies that require technical support. It is available for Windows, Linux and Solaris.
Personally, I have only used StarOffice a long time ago (10 years ago, to be exact), when I bought my first new PC (a Pentium MMX@200 Mhz with 32 MB of RAM), that came bundled with an OEM version of it. This was before StarOffice was bought by Sun. At that time, it run of Windows 95 and supported MS Office 95 formats.

What is the Google Pack?



The Google Pack is a free (of charge, not necessarily FOSS) software pack, selected by Google, for the MS Windows XP/Vista operating systems. It currently includes Google Earth, Google Toolbar for Internet Explorer (argh!), Norton Security Scan, Spyware Doctor Starter Edition, Google Desktop, Picasa, Mozilla Firefox with Google Toolbar, Google Photos Screensaver, Adobe Reader, Google Talk, Skype, RealPlayer, and now StarOffice. It is an interesting software pack, if you new to computers or just want to have a good software base quickly. The interesting part for me is that StarOffice is available free of charge, when normally it is sold.

Until next time, may you enjoy a good software pack.

entry.title: Pandora
entry.content:
Today I have finished reading "Pandora", the first book in the New Tales of the Vampires book series, by Anne Rice.


Here be spoilers

In this book, Pandora confides her tale to David Talbot, which is entwined with the tale of Marius (as told by Lestat in "The Vampire Lestat"). The story takes place from ancient Rome to the city of Antioch. Pandora is roman highborn who is exiled (and thus assume the Greek name) after her family was executed under the accusation of betrayal of the emperor. The story is also connected to Akasha, through the cult of Isis.

My tale

First of all, let me tell that the "New Tales Of The Vampires" is a marketing move, as it is no different than the remaining vampire chronicles. That said, I really enjoyed at, as the Pandora character was finally unveiled, as well as her relationship with Marius. But mostly, I just enjoyed returning to the Egyptian mythology and ancient Roman empire culture.
It is worth noticing some brief criticism on the origin and development of Christianism, showing Anne Rice's intelligence. Regarding sexuality, there is nothing new (there is another male character who enjoys boys), only a rather frustrated vampire sexual penetration.
Regarding Anne Rice's mythology, a hint is given that vampires may grow new powers with each century, at least as to explain why Lestat and David are able to see spirits (something that was stated as not possible in "The Queen Of The Damned"). Finally, the book ends with the mention of a creepy scarecrow character, something which I suspect will never be truly revealed in her books.

Until next time, may you enjoy opening the box, and after all, finding some hope.

entry.title: Why Linux will never be a successful operating system
entry.content:
Today I give you my opinion on why GNU/Linux distributions will fail as mainstream operating systems, and alternatives for proprietary systems like MS Windows and Apple MacOS X. Well, at least a small summary, a complete discussion would take more than this post. Anyway, this analysis reflects my experience and expectations as both a desktop user and software developer role. Oh, and unlike some, I actually use Linux, not just talk about it.

What is not the problem

The problem is not that Linux systems are FOSS (Free or Open-Source Software). Actually, I believe that the future of software will most certainly converge to FOSS, save in some niches.
It is also not a problem with this Unix-like architecture, as MacOS X is a Unix system, and has been quite successful.

The problem: software installation

Lets get to the point: software installation in Linux sucks. Big time. Its hard, complicated, it's a mess. And I am a geek, I am a pretty patient guy. Common users are not.
Sure, there are a lot of good installation engines, front-ends, and repositories (take a look at autopackage for instance), but all of these do not actually solve the problem, they merely mitigate it. And why does all of this happens? Because, while all of these people developing the engines may have optimized and modularized the installation procedure, but they forgot a known issue in software engineering: coupling. All of these installation systems are based on the premise that installing an application is a modular procedure. It is not! Users want to install an application in one package. They do not care if the package is twice as big if it works. They don't care if the redundant library will use an extra 200 KiB or RAM, because it is not dynamically linked. And they certainly don't want to compile an application. An operating system, no matter how advanced and sophisticated as it is, will never be an interesting alternative, unless users can actually use it.

Other issues

Other issues trouble the Linux user. Still on the installation issues, I remember a time when you downloaded an installation package for your distribution. These days you have to download a package for a specific version of your distribution, using a specific installation engine. There are simple too much software variety. I mean its good to have an ecosystem with some variety, but it is not very good when you have a complete anarchy, in which no one wants to collaborate, but only live on their small world. Have you ever noticed the amount of time that Linux supporters spend discussing which distribution is better? Get a life!
As such, we got to a point where the life-expectancy of a Linux installation is very short, when compared to Windows. For instance, the laptop I am using right now has two and a half years of existence. At the time I bought it, I've installed Windows XP Professional SP-2 and Fedora Core 3. Today, I can still install all of my favourite software in Windows but I can't get anything new on Fedora Core 4 (it was updated since) without running into dependency hell, except for statically compiled applications (such as Firefox and Thunderbird), or good old Java applications. I don't know about you, but I have far more interesting things to do than install a new OS every 6 months in every computer I use.
With all of these issues, it is going to be hard to get hardware manufactorers to support Linux drivers. Some big companies, such as HP, have given some effort into that, but still these are "unofficial" drivers (which simply means there is no costumer support for them - use it at your own risk). Back to my laptop example, after all this time I have still no web cam or SD card reader while using Linux - a waste of hardware (there goes the argument that Linux lets you take advantage of your hardware).

Wrapping up

Linux has been my default OS for some time, but sadly, it is no longer going to be. At least, not until I have a clean and simple OS.

Until next time, may you enjoy having a new opinion, even if you don't like it.

entry.title: Nvu & Komposer
entry.content:
Today, I'm just posting some information on two FOSS HTML editors, based on Gecko: Nvu and Komposer.

Nvu ("N-view")

Nvu 1.0.0 running on Fedora Core 4

So, what is Nvu? Nvu is an open-source WYSIWYG HTML Editor, similar to FrontPage or Dreamweaver. Although not having all the features these proprietary tools have, it is an interesting alternative. It is available for the usual platforms (Linux, MacOS X and Windows), and since it is based on Gecko, all the Firefox/Thunderbird users will recognize the interface. Unlike those, however, Nvu is not supported by Mozilla, but by Linspire Inc., authors of the Linspire GNU/Linux distribution.
As posted before, I have been using Nvu for building static web sites for some time (check my personal or master thesis web sites for examples). I confess that I was never a big fan of HTML editors (I preferred to code it myself using an advanced text editor, such as Edit+ or gedit), but I must admit that for simple text editing, these tools really speed up things. The first time I used Nvu was when I had to maintain two static web sites for conference workshops. The thing was that I had to reuse the look, and these sites were made in Frontpage, which meant that the code was not really human-readable. As such, I decided to give it try. Well, it turned out to be a cool tool, at least for XHTML/CSS editing. The problem is that Nvu has a lot of bugs (really, a lot of them). And Linspire only made public releases until 1.0.0 (in 2005). Since then the project is under closed development...

Kompozer

Kompozer 0.7.10 running on Windows XP


... but the open-source community really enjoyed the tool, and so a couple of nice geeks decided to take the 1.0.0 release source code a produce a fixed version of Nvu. And thus, Komposer was born! So, yesterday I decided to download it and give it try. Hopefully, it will not crash so often, and maybe these guys can implement some of the missing features (such as frameset coding, for example).

Until next time, may you enjoy a new view.

entry.title: SWERC 2007
entry.content:
Last weekend, I was a student volunteer for the ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest's South Western European Regional Contest (SWERC) 2007, which was hosted at the computer science department of my faculty.


The Contest

A couple of yellow shirts

Well, putting it very simple it was an international programming contest in which 64 teams (a base 2 number, of course!) competed for the best time in solving a set of programming/algorithmic problems. The interesting part is that every time a team solved a problem, they were awarded with a balloon. The colour of the balloon indicated which problem was solved.

The staff

Me and my master thesis supervisor, Pedro Guerreiro

Each part of the staff was assigned a different t-shirt colour: yellow for volunteers, blue for technical staff, and black for judges. Contestants wore a white t-shirt, and coaches used a red one. As a volunteer, I did a couple of interesting tasks: door man, room watching, runner, and corridor master (and before the actual contest, I also carried computers and screens from a room to another). The volunteers were all in a good mood, and we did have some fun. As an interesting fact, I've noticed that I was probably one the oldest volunteers (and one of the few that already graduated), and oldest that most contestants and coaches... maybe it's time to leave the university ;)
One of the volunteers, Ana Figueiras, wrote a nice entry on her blog on the event, and also took a lot of pictures (namely the ones I'm using here), which are available at a picasa album.

Wrapping up

Well, I never did participate in this kind of extra-curricular activities, so I took my probable last change to do so, and I do not regret it. It was a fun weekend.

Until next time, may you find a little time that you can give to others.

entry.title: Busted!
entry.content: Until next time, may you enjoy being photographed in an unexpected place.

entry.title: 50 Metal Albums
entry.content:
I am unsure why, but I have decided to present with some 50 Metal music albums which I particularly enjoy (well, it was supposed the top 100, but that would be too much work).

After Forever - Prison of Desire (2000)

After Forever's debut album, it has some very cool tracks, including "Beyond Me" featuring Sharon den Adel, from Within Temptation. It also featured the first "The Embrace That Smothers" trilogy, which would later be continued in Epica, a spin-off band. Since the departure of the band leader to Epice, the band changed a little, reason why this is the album from the band in this list.

Apocalyptica - Inquisition Symphony (1998)

Yes, you're probably saying "Apocalyptica is not a metal band". So what? They've captured the metal "soul" in Cello very well. Anyway, this is not the band's debut album, but much better, since it is not focused on Metallica.

Apocalyptica - Cult (2001)

The band's third album continued to delight me, as they've introduced lyrics in their music, namely by featuring Sandra NasiÄ from Guano Apes. Further albums of this band used too much synthesisers, reason why they have their appeal to me.

Avantasia - The Metal Opera Part I (2001)

Avantasia was a nice project from members of several bands (Stratovarius, EdGuy, Within Temptation), whose result was a metal opera, not in the sense as a Symphonic Metal Opera (like Therion), but as story which was sung, similarly as an Opera.

Avantasia - The Metal Opera Part II (2002)

The second part was a little better. Pity that both of them only contained a song each with Sharon den Adel :(

Blind Guardian - The Forgotten Tales (1996)

The cover album compilation shows that Power Metal bands can have a great sense of humour. Rock classics as "Barbara Ann" and "Surfin' USA" gained a whole new dimension. The "Mr Sandman" track is one of my favourite Christmas songs (right after "Gothic Christmas" promo track by Within Temptation). And of course, their was "Lord Of The Rings", a great homage to J.R.R. Tolkien's classic book trilogy.

Blind Guardian - Nightfall In Middle Earth (1998)

Since the band is great fan of Tolkien's universe, they've decided to homage "The Silmarillion" in this conceptual album. The story telling drives into this world fantasy, allow with the great metal tracks. It is a pity that the band never got to participate into the LOTR movie soundtrack.

Domine - Emperor Of The Black Runes (2003)
Epica - The Phantom Agony (2003)
Epica - The Score - An Epic Journey (2005)
Epica - The Divine Conspiracy (2007)
Evanescence - Fallen (2003)
Evanescence - The Open Door (2006)

Iced Earth - The Dark Saga (1996)

Lacuna Coil - Comalies (2004)
Leaves' Eyes - Vinland Saga (2005)
Metallica - Ride the Lightning (1984)
Metallica - Master of Puppets (1986)
Metallica - ...And Justice for All (1988)
Metallica - Metallica (1990)
Metallica - Garage Inc. (1998)
Moonspell - Wolfheart (1995)
Moonspell - Irreligious (1996)
Moonspell - Darkness And Hope (2001)
Nemesea - Mana (2004)
Nightwish - Angels Fall First (1997)
Nightwish - Oceanborn (1998)
Nightwish - Wishmaster (2000)

Nightwish - Once (2004)

entry.title: Merrick
entry.content:
This week, I have finished reading "Merrick", the 7th vampire chronicle by Anne Rice.


Here be spoilers

In this book, David Talbot seeks an old lover: Merrick, a Mayfair witch. Together with Louis, they seek to summon the ghost of Claudia, in order to make her rest in piece...
This book is focused on an untold (in "The Tale Of The Body Thief") period of David Talbot's life, his relation with Merrick and the Talamasca. We are also introduced with the Mayfair Witches universe (which is a trilogy of books by Anne Rice).

My chronicle

I enjoyed this book much more than the previous one ("The Vampire Armand"). This book has a lot more action, and nicely crossovers the vampire and witch universes of Anne Rice. I particularly enjoyed how witchcraft and religion mingle so well into the vampire mythology. The ending was little surprising, but not too surprising, since one comes to expect a certain twist at the end of her books.
Sexuality is always present in Rice's books, as well as the usual deviations (apparently, David is also fond of little boys and girls...). Almost at the end of the book, there is a little confession on Merrick's behalf over what the condition of being a woman, which was real interesting, following the same line of dissertations over mankind that Akasha offered the reader in "The Queen Of The Damned".

Coming up

As I was reading this book I have come to realize that the "New Tales Of The Vampires" (a two book series on vampires) are chronologically between the 5th and 7th "Vampire Chronicles", and such, I should have read them by now. As such, I'm going to make a little detour to read these two books (I have already started reading "Pandora"), as well the Mayfair Witches trilogy, as soon as I acquire them.

Until next time, may you enjoy the summoning of a troubled soul.

entry.title: My Firefox/Thunderbird extensions
entry.content:
Just advertising a couple of useful extensions I use in my favorite Mozilla applications: Firefox and Thunderbird.

DownThemAll!



Need a download manager? Then you can use this one inside Firefox and Thunderbird (as well as Seamonkey, Flock and Netscape, if anyone uses those), in any platform. While I'm not a big fan of this type applications, this is one is very straightforward. And the speedup can be useful when you are in a hurry to download something.

HTML Validator



If you are are a web developer (or a plain geek - like me), this is a really useful tool, since it saves you the time of using the W3C web site for HTML and CSS validation. It is available for Firefox and Mozilla, in Windows and Linux (IA32).

Lightning



The calendar project at Mozilla offers you Lightning, an add-on that turns Thunderbird into a nice scheduler, compatible with iCalendar and even Outlook (argh!). If you don't use Thunderbird, you can check out Sunbird, the standalone version. Both are available for the usual operating systems: Windows, Linux x86 and Mac OS X.

There is a world out there

There is a world of add-ons for Mozilla applications out there (some people even compete for to see who can install most plug-ins...). While installing a zillion of them won't be very good for you, some can really replace some applications, just try the search engine. Personally, I can't live without the dictionaries (for blogging and emailing). And sometimes, you can find that application that you badly need it (once I needed a CHM reader in Ubuntu Linux, and this one saved the day).

Until next time, may you enjoy extending you favorite applications.

entry.content:
Yet another song - Circle - this one from the Italian band Lacuna Coil.

What is it for?
What is sacred?
In my circle of regrets...
Circle of regrets

Today I'm drawing circles -
In my memory, in the pages of my life...

That's me for a long time
I can't run away... (long time)

These stone tears are falling down on me, all my regrets!
There stone tears are falling down on me, all my regrets! (I don't want this feeling...)

I need more
All I want is to break
My circle of regrets
Circle of regrets
Is there any solution ?
I want to find the way to escape... to go away.

Until next time, may enjoy hoping to one day break your circle of regrets.

entry.title: Anne Rice: Between Christ and Vampires
entry.content:
If you are familiar with my blog, you may have known that I am a big fan of her books on vampirism and witchcraft. What you may not known is that she has recently converted into Christianism (and has decided to write Christ the Lord, Out of Egypt). However, she is having some troubles reconciling her fans. Two months ago, she wrote an interesting essay on the matter ("On the Nature of My Earlier Works"), at her web site. Since there is no direct link to it, I decided to copy it and share the full text here.

Until next time, may you enjoy reconciling opinions.

0.01 * 10 == 0.099999994

...if you are using single precision floating-point variables, also known as floats in C#. The solution? Using the decimal data type (or, if you are a Java developer, the BigDecimal class).
Although I didn't test it, this seems to be an issue in several similar programming languages, which use IEEE 754 data types. The problem is that not all real decimal numbers are directly representable in binary (e.g. 0.01), and as such are approximated. The solution involves using a special binary notation to support the accuracy required for financial applications.

Until next time, may you enjoy being surprised with something you though for sure it was true, but it was not, and you should have known better.

entry.title: After Forever @ Lisbon
entry.content:
Last month, the 21st of September, the goth metal band After Forever was in Lisbon.

Bizarra Locomotiva

The opening band was Bizarra Locomotiva ("Bizarre Locomotive"), a Portuguese metal band, which somewhat resembles Rammstein. They make a lot of nice, they dress strangely, the lyrics are in their mother tongue, and there is some bizarre sexual attitude in their stage performance. Other than that, the vocalist had a very "interesting" stage presence, by stage diving in the first minutes (ouch!), and by jumping into the audience for some mayhem.



After Forever



After Forever was the main band. Although I have been accompanying the band's records since the first two albums, before Mark Jansen's departure from the band, and consequent formation of Epica. Anyway, they played some songs from Prison Of Desire and Decipher. As a nice treat, they still played a nice cover, For Whom The Bell Tolls, from Metallica's early days. The final song was the moment I was waiting for, one of the parts of The Embrace That Smothers (a 9 part triple trilogy of songs which expanded from After Forever to Epica) - Follow in the Cry.



"Behind your facade hides an indomitable
lust for power and tyranny
Taking advantage of your pendencies

Fear is the doom, doom of us all
Instead of exterminating the weed
We allow it to overgrow our function

All means are justified for the "djihad fi sabil Allah"

I embrace you, accept my soul
I shall make my life subordinate to you
Live like your rules and laws prescribe
and follow you wherever I go

Follow in the cry

Hang this heretic who's indulged in unchaste thoughts
Silence him such as the laws of the vellums prescribe
Pusillanimous massacres the order of the day
On behalf of power-hungry fundamentalists"



Tuatara

Tuatara (roughly translated as "your (moral) deficiency") is a nice bar in Lisbon, which hosted the concerts. Although it was a small place, it was enough for the small audience in that night. It had some nice air fans which made breathing bearable, just bearable.


Photos courtesy of Ricardo Silvestre.

Until next time, may enjoy the embrace that smothers.

entry.title: The Vampire Armand
entry.content:
I have just finished reading "The Vampire Armand", the sixth vampire chronicle, by Anne Rice.



Here be spoilers

As you may have guessed, this book records the tale of Armand, which had a significant role in the "Interview with the Vampire", as leader of the ThÃ©Ã¢tre des Vampires. In this book, we are told of his early life in Russia, deeply influenced by his religion; as well as his relation with Marius in Venice, on which most of the book is based. Afterwards, we are told about his ascension as Coven leader and Devil-Worshipper in Paris, and eventually as part of the Theatre. Finally, he resumes his suicide attempt on the previous book, after Lestat's return from Hell, and his new mortal companions.

My opinion

My first feeling about this book was a little disappointment, since Lestat is not the main character. Also, there is a slower rhythm than in previous books, and no great revelations like in "Memnoch the Devil" and "Queen of the Damned".
In terms of sexuality, there is an unsettling touch of homosexuality and paedophilia between Marius and Armand, which may shock the uncanny reader.
Still, the book was worth reading. Armand's obsession with the Appassionata, (which, as a side note, I am listening as a write these words) is very interesting. Possibly the best chapter is the final one, where the story is once again twisted, when Armand discovers the fate of his human companions, and Marius' disappointment on humanity...

Until next time, may enjoy another vampire chronicle.

entry.title: GTTSE 2007
entry.content:
Earlier this month, I participated in the 2nd Summer School on Generative and Transformational Techniques in Software Engineering (GTTSE 2007).

The Place

The event was hosted by the Universidade do Minho, in the Hotel da Falperra. The hotel was really nice, with good rooms, meals, and of course two swimming pools and a jacuzzi, to relax a little :) The organization was quite good, although they did a little mess up with the parallel sessions. I got the change to meet a lot researchers, especially portuÃ±ol speakers :)

Lectures

We had six of lectures, from tutorials, technology presentations, to a participants workshop. First of all, generative programming is not my actual research line (actually, I don't do research any more, but when I was doing, it was on Aspect-Oriented Software Development), so I didn't find most of the lectures all that interesting. Having said that, Krzysztof Czarnecki's tutorial was particularly enlightening; Jean-Marie Favre's presentation was very amusing and demonstrated a truly "out of the box" thinking. In terms of technology presentations Scott Blum's presentation on the Google Web Toolkit was quite pragmatic; Perdita Stevens' rhetoric was very necessary (as in every research line).




Culture

During our stay there we had some time to get to know interesting places, such as Museu Nogueira da Silva, Porto and Braga's river side, and Taylor's wine cellars.



Until next time, may you enjoy having lectures in the summer.

entry.title: C#: a first look
entry.content:
I have recently started working with the C# programming language and the .Net framework.

The language (C#)

I started off with the notion that C# was Microsoft's version of Java, but that was it. After spending a weekend reading Inside C#, I got a pretty good idea on the language. My impression is that C# philosophy is quite different than Java's. While Java aims at being an elegant, minimalist language, with each new version making few changes in the Java platform; C# is a somewhat more programmer-friendly language, with as many bells and whistles as possible (this is actually a reflex of the different backgrounds and philosophies between Sun Microsystems and Microsoft).
As such, here are some things I liked about C#:
  • smart properties - it was about time someone recognized getters and setters as first class constructs;
  • overriding the '[]' brackets - this little syntactic sugar trick can make source code a lot easier and intuitive to read, by allowing that any class can work as an array;
  • structs - while this may seem not very Object-Oriented, it works well through the unified type model, since it is basically syntactic sugar for a class design pattern for storing data (no wonder it is a pending RFE for Java);
  • unsigned number types - correctly typed variables are very important;
  • delegates - while not strictly necessary, it is a nice alternative to Java's anonymous classes;
  • mandatory break statement in each case - while a small detail, this little rule eliminates a lot of nasty bugs using the switch statement;
On the other hand, there are other things which I didn't like at all:
  • polymorphism - having the possibility of defining methods which are not dynamically dispatched when overridden is a bad idea, since it basically breaks one of the core principles of Object-Oriented Programming: the substitution principle.
  • no throws clause - big mistake there, sure you can use the <exception> tag on documentation, but you don't have to, and still think that the best documentation is the source code itself;
  • the goto statement - I'm not dogmatic about this, but come on, even Kerninghan and Ritchie recognized that you really don't need this;
  • ref and out keywords - while this may be useful sometimes, I think it is a bad programming technique: methods should only return one value, period. If you need more than one, then you either need a new class to group these objects, or you are designing your class wrong;
  • XML documentation - this was almost a good idea. While it interesting to produce XML documentation, it is too verbose to read and write. They could have done something like javadocs and parsed it into XML, for transformation and documentation support.
  • overriding casts - maybe I'm wrong, but it doesn't seem like a good idea...

The environment (Visual Studio)

Regarding Visual Studio 2005 (.Net 2.0), there are a couple of things I would like to point out:
  • Auto completion works pretty well, including some new tricks, like completing parametric classes correctly.
  • Refactoring support is nice, but not as good as Eclipse.
  • Some source code options would be appreciated (namely automatic creation of constructors and getters/setters).
  • Produced documentation is a little too colourful and clumsy. Keep it simple. Take a look at Javadocs.
Until next time, may you enjoy joining the dark side (of software development).

entry.title: CITI - End of the contract
entry.content:
May was my final month at CITI. This is the end of an eight month cycle.


Work

Over these months, I have been working in the SOFTAS project as research assistant. Basically I have been doing (aspect-oriented) requirement engineering, as well as refactoring some code. And writing papers, also...

Study

In the meanwhile, I have been attending my final two courses: Reasoning in the Semantic Web, and Advanced Topics on Software Engineering. Also, I have been writing (hopefully) most of my master thesis, which should be finished somewhere until the end of the year.

People

The people at the office here are the same people of the ASSD team at Uninova, namely:
  • Ricardo Ferreira: the expert on web services, MOF-compliant jokes, as well the hacker behind GYM;
  • Ricardo Raminhos: the prophet that separated ETL in two, as well as the only person who understands Star Trek references and jokes;
  • AndrÃ© Marques: the expert on concern composition, as well as the guy with no luck at all.
Future

Well, currently I am desperately looking for a job, and going most of the days to CITI until I finish my courses. Also, I am finishing some research papers. In July, I'll still be attending a summer school.

Until next time, may you enjoy looking for a job.

Ever since I saw episode 2x01 of the TV series "Lost", I found myself hearing this song all the time. I am talking about Cass Elliot's "Make You Own Kind of Music", a song whose lyrics have (in my opinion) an uncommon wisdom.

Nobody can tell ya;
There's only one song worth singin'.
They may try and sell ya,
'cause it hangs them up
to see somone like you.

But you've gotta make your own kind of music
sing your own special song,
make your own kind of music even if nobody
else sing along.

So if you cannot take my hand,
and if you must be goin',
I will understand.

You're gonna be knowing
the loneliest kind of lonely.
It may be rough goin',
just to do your thing's
the hardest thing to do.

But you've gotta make your own kind of music
sing your own special song,
make your own kind of music even if nobody
else sings along.

So if you cannot take my hand,
and if you must be goin',
I will understand.

You gotta make your own kind of music
sing your own special song,
make your own kind of music even if nobody
else sings along.

Until next time, may you enjoy making you own kind of music... even if nobody else sings along.

entry.title: Memnoch the Devil
entry.content:
Last week, I have finished reading "Memnoch the Devil", another book in the Vampire Chronicles series by Anne Rice.


Here be spoilers

In this book, Lestat is once again the main character. The book starts as he stalking his next victim, a drug baron. However, after killing his victim he is confronted with something new: the victim's ghost, with a special request. Afterwards he gets an unexpected visit, from the Devil himself. The Devil has a proposition for him...

My opinion

This book takes another step in the vampire chronicles, when finally he get the answer to the big question: does God exist? This is an issue that was present ever since she introduced spiritualism in the second book, but finally we get the answer. To be honest, I was a little disappointed at first, since the answer is yes, and God is (apparently) has Christianism tells you. I was expecting something like, God exists, but not at all as most people think. Well, actually I wasn't disappointed. As the book progresses, Memnoch (the Devil) tells the tale of creation, and Anne Rice builds a very impressive theological theory. It is fairly coherent and integrates evolutionary biology, as well as ideas borrowed from other religions, such as Hinduism (reincarnation) and Summerian mythology (the "Sheol" concept). But, best of all, God and the Devil are not as one would expect, since neither of them represents good or evil. The only point I think it is flawed is the fact that angels and God always choose to incarnate men, instead of women.
Lestat himself keeps growing as a character. In this book, he shows a lot of fear, devotion, and that ability of keeping the reader surprised by choosing the strangest decisions. In terms of vampirism, you get the confirmation that vampires can't grow amputed members, but can reintegrate them (as hinted in the second book). Finally, the book introduces a new erotic theme, with Lestat's obsession with a character's menstrual blood.
In summary, the author took a big risk of disappointing both religious as atheist people, but I think she did a pretty good job. Of course I would prefer the chronicles progressed as atheist, but hey, sometimes its good being surprised.

Until next time, may enjoy reading the tale of the Devil.
