Hoje, dia 25 Abril, faz 33 anos que ocorreu a revoluÃ§Ã£o dos cravos. Como nÃ£o era nascido na altura, nÃ£o sei como foi viver no "estado novo", nem tÃ£o pouco passar pelo perÃ­odo revolucionÃ¡rio. De qualquer maneira, acho que tenho direito a uma opiniÃ£o.

HÃ¡ coisas que me entristecem. Ainda ontem Ã  noite, encontrava-me num autocarro que esteve preso no trÃ¢nsito devido a um desfile comemorativo da revoluÃ§Ã£o, e assisti Ã  indignaÃ§Ã£o geral das pessoas que "queriam ir para casa". Entristece-me assistir a estas cenas, pela demonstraÃ§Ã£o de falta de compreensÃ£o Ã  memÃ³ria deste dia. Entristece-me, porque muitas dessas pessoas viveram sobre a opressÃ£o dictatorial. Os homens (aqueles que nÃ£o fugiram), tiveram de combater numa guerra, com a qual provavelmente nem concoradavam. SerÃ¡ que se esqueceram?

"O 25 de Abril foi sÃ³ para alguns", dizem muitos. Ã verdade que a revoluÃ§Ã£o nÃ£o resolveu todos os problemas do paÃ­s. Ã verdade que muitas pessoas e grupos souberam aproveitar a oportunidade para beneficiar da situaÃ§Ã£o. Ã verdade que o paÃ­s ainda tem muitos problemas, muitos dos quais vÃªm dessa altura. Mas o paÃ­s deu um passo em frente.

"O que esta gente precisava agora era de outro Salazar", dizem outros. Ã verdade que no estado novo nÃ£o existiam certos problemas que afligem hoje a sociedade, mas era uma ilusÃ£o. VÃ­viamos sobre uma ilusÃ£o, porque vivÃ­amos fechados, controlados, oprimidos.

"Na altura havia respeito", dizem outros. Talvez, mas sobretudo havia medo. E medo e respeito nÃ£o sÃ£o a mesma coisa. A Liberdade nÃ£o Ã© de graÃ§a, nÃ£o Ã© simples, e tem de ser lutada constantemente.

"Este paÃ­s estÃ¡ cada vez pior", dizem muitos. Pode ser que esteja. Mas se o estÃ¡, nÃ£o Ã© por culpa dos outros. A responsibilidade Ã© de todos nÃ³s. Toda a geraÃ§Ã£o que viveu a pÃ³s-revoluÃ§Ã£o, e todas as geraÃ§Ãµes subsequentes. A Liberdade e um paÃ­s melhor somos nÃ³s que o fazemos, no dia a dia, em todas as nossas acÃ§Ãµes. FazÃªmo-lo na nossa casa, no nosso trabalho, na rua, na paragem do autocarro e no supermercado, quando nos esforÃ§amos por ser melhores, para nÃ³s e pelos outros. Isso Ã© Liberdade.

AtÃ© Ã  prÃ³xima, que consigam aproveitar a Liberdade para tentar fazer um mundo melhor.

entry.title: Hatha Yoga
entry.content:
Last month I have started practising Hatha Yoga.

A very nice picture I have found in Wikipedia

Yoga what?

Hatha Yoga is one type of Yoga. While "traditional" Hatha Yoga is a rather complex path (which includes philosophy and meditation), most Yoga in the West is practised as an exercise, and as such is based on a subset of it, namely on asanas (postures) and pranayamas (breathing control).

Me and Yoga

Since I have started only a month ago, it is difficult to really evaluate it, but I'll give it a try. I practise Hatha Yoga in a nearby gym twice a week, one hour and fifteen minutes each class. My motivation to start practising is to achieve relaxation, improve my health, and to get more involved with my body. None of this happens overnight, it is a long-term objective, but I believe it is an interesting path.
I have found Yoga practise accessible to most people (several old ladies go there), although hard to master. Most exercises are kind of hard for me, since I have a pretty bad physical shape (I haven't practised any sport for a long time...), but I have no shame on saying on telling it :). Breathing is essential, as well as relaxation (asanas are very difficult to perform if you are not relaxed). My favourite asanas are the ones focused on the spine, I find them very liberating and energizing. A specific sequence of asanas and pranayanas is the Sun salutation, which is used for warm-up (check this nice video, which shows how to perform it, in a similar way as we do). The mantras (chants in sanskrit) are also interesting, such as the Mahamrityunjaya Mantra (which we chant every class).

Spiritualism?

For those of you who are aware of my opinions regarding the world, you might have noticed that I am an atheist. Doesn't this collide with Yoga? Good question. The physical part (asanas/pranayanas) is simple, but how about mantras? Well, although some mantras do mention some deities (such as Shiva), it is interpretation is somewhat dependent on the translation. Most mantras that I have read represent rather universal thoughts, so it does not concern me at all. Either way, they do not have to have to interpreted literally, simply what some people think as spiritual exercise, I see as psychological/breathing exercise which involves some practise (it is sanskrit!) and sharing. Does it make a difference? I think not.

Until next time, may enjoy the path for your balance of mind and body.

entry.title: The Tale of the Body Thief
entry.content:
This week I have finished reading "The Tale Of The Body Thief", the fourth book of the Vampire Chronicles of Anne Rice.


Here be spoilers

This book continues the story after the events in Queen of the Damned, of our favourite character: Lestat. Lestat's depression follows the break of the coven of "the children of the millennia", when only David Talbot (from Talamasca) is his only friend, although we keeps refusing the "dark gift". After failing his suicide, Lestat meets Reglan James, someone who proposes to exchange bodies with him temporarily. However, things don't go exactly as planned...

My opinion

The fourth book of the chronicles didn't disappoint me. Lestat is still a very rich character, and this book shows it. Unlike previous books, the story is not based on flashbacks and stories from ancient times - the action is all in the 20th century. The book is based mainly on three characters mentioned in the previous paragraph, the remaining from the previous books having few or none participation, despite being frequently mentioned. In terms of vampirism, there is little development (with the exception of Lestat's reaction to direct sunlight ), but some new fantasy elements are mentioned (lycanthropy) or developed (possession and body exchange). As for theology, there are some interesting discussions through out the book between David and Lestat, regarding the role of the Devil(s), and a pantheistic conception of God. Perhaps Anne Rice was at the time discussing this with herself?...

Until next time, may you enjoy trying somebody else's shoes.

entry.title: BOINC!
entry.content:
Last week I have started using BOINC!



What's BOINC?

Well, before telling you what this is, I have to tell you another story. Several years ago, a couple of researchers created the SETI (Search for Extra-Terrestrial Inteligence) project, of which Carl Sagan was one of the people that was deeply involved. The project consists, in very simple terms, in gathering and analysing radio signals from space in order to find a pattern which could prove that there is another sentient life form species in outer space. Since this is not a prioritary project, it had problems with financing for a long time. One of their problems is that the gathered data demanded a very large processing capability.

SETI@Home



However, some years ago, with the growth of the Internet, the SETI@Home project appeared. Very simply, SETI@Home was a distributed system that distributed "chunks" of data for clients to process, and return the results. A client is a volunteer with a small software installed in the computer. The software fecthes and processes data when the CPU usage is low, or as screensaver. This way, people that have a PC connected to the internet could better use the resources for a "greater good" :)

BOINC!

As the project revealed to be popular (people around the globe compete to be in the rankings, and even form teams), researchers at Berkeley decided to create a meta-project for SETI@Home: BOINC (Berkeley Open Infrastructure for Network Computing). This is essencially a middleware for distributed systems such as the one used in the SETI@HOME project. Today, there are over 20 projects that you can choose from (in such areas as: Physics, Chemistry, Astronomy, Biology, Climate prediction, etc) to use in your spare CPU cycles. Also, it makes a nice screensaver ;)

Your contribution

Come on, you don't spend any more power for that (well, unless you have multicore processor or a laptop, in which case power consumption can scale according to CPU usage). All you need is a computer and an Internet connection (BOINC runs on Windows, Linux, MacOSX and Solaris).
I now have a desktop PC dedicated to BOINC and eMule on weekends :)

Until next time, may you enjoy discovering an alien or a cure for a disease.

entry.title: I, Lucifer
entry.content:
Last year I have read a book called "I, Lucifer" from Glen Duncan.Here be spoilers

This book is, as may have guessed, about the fallen angel Lucifer, "the light bringer", AKA Satan, "the opponent", AKA the Devil. He decides to tell his side of the story, by taking possession of the body of a suicidal writer called Declan Gunn (yeah, an anagram of Glen Duncan). Also, he decides to do some changes in his life. On the other hand, God has a proposition for him.

My opinion

This black humour book is very interesting, both in the story of Lucifer as the story of Declan Gunn. The author did his homework, since the book is filled with religious references. The story is told in a way that you get to simpathize Lucifer and Declan, which is for me the most interesting part of the book. The humour itself is not best I have read: making politically incorrect jokes is nice, when the jokes are actually good, otherwise it's just dumb (ok, the portuguese version doesn't help either - lots of jokes got lost in translation). The nice thing is the book becomes better as it progresses.

Movie?

According to IMDB, a movie based on the book is under production, and is schedlued for next year. That should be interesting!

  • A despenalizaÃ§Ã£o nÃ£o vai resolver todos os problemas. Concordo, nÃ£o vai resolver, mas irÃ¡ atenuar bastantes. Ficar tudo na mesma Ã© que de certeza nÃ£o vai ajudar.   • O aborto Ã© um trauma para mulher. (Bom, ignorando os famosos "estudos cientÃ­ficos" que muito foram discutidos, e sobre os quais nÃ£o tenho conhecimento.) Claro que Ã© um trauma para a mulher. AtÃ© pode ser um trauma para o pai. Mas e (mais) uma crianÃ§a indesejada no mundo, nÃ£o Ã© um trauma?
Outras questÃµes
Existem outras questÃµes, que nÃ£o abordei atrÃ¡s por serem questÃµes morais e/ou filosÃ³ficas, que repito, nÃ£o sÃ£o o que este referendo aborda. Estou a falar das questÃµes do "direito Ã  vida". Trata-se de uma revista pequena, bimensal, online e gratuita que aborda alguns artigos sobre o assunto. Ainda nÃ£o li nenhuma, mas parece-me que Ã© um projecto com algum futuro, visto nÃ£o existir nada parecido (pelo menos que conheÃ§a). A experimentar, pelo profissional ou pelo curioso.

AtÃ© Ã  prÃ³xima, apreciem essa nobre ocupaÃ§Ã£o, programar.

entry.title: Zombies!!!
entry.content:
I start this blogging year with everyone's favourite theme: zombies!!!


Zombies?

During this new year's eve celebration a friend brought us a nice little game: zombies!!! This is a board/card game for 2 to 6 players. Each player has a character that must survive in a zombie-flooded town and either - reach the heliport, or kill 25 zombies. Oh, and there is only one seat in that helicopter...
Think of it as Magic: the Gathering meets Monopoly (yeah, its a bad example, but it is the best I can think of). It is a board game with dice like Monopoly, but with cards, life and ammunition, somewhat like Magic. But, the most important - it is not as complex as Magic (so anyone can play it) and not so boring as Monopoly (everyone wants to play it).

Experience


The table start-up

The game is quite simple, but enjoyable. The dice roll makes the game a little RPG-like; the card drawing gives it a Magic like strategy; and the tile drawing makes sure that you have enough randomness to make each game unique. And the gory art and humour (Evil Dead and Romero fans will recognize the references) makes the game very cool!

The table at the late game

More Zombies?

Yes, there are more zombies. Twilight Creations (the guys that make the game) made a couple of expansions and add-ons (yeah, Magic influence) and a spin-off game: Zombies!!! MidEvil (Army Of Darkness anyone?). To do: try it some day!

Until next time, may you enjoy fresh victims for the ever growing army of the undead.

entry.title: My FOSS List
entry.content:
Today I bring my final post (this year) in the blog, with my FOSS list.

FOSS who?

Free or Open-Source Software (FOSS). That means software that you have at least access to its source code, and depending on its license more or less freedom to use, modify and redistribute. Not to be mistaken with freeware, software at no cost. Although usually free software is also free in terms of price, it is above all free in terms of freedom of use. The classical example, is free as in free beer versus free as in freedom of speech.

Licenses and platforms

The platform is important to know if you can use the software:
  • Win32: any 32 bit MS Windows operating system (Windows family 9x: 95, 98, ME; Windows family NT: NT 4, 2000, XP, 2003) and probably the most recent operating systems (Windows XP and 2000 64 bit; Windows Vista).
  • Linux: any GNU/Linux distribution, with the usual library dependencies.
  • OS X: any Apple MacOS X system.
  • *BSD: any BSD based operating system (FreeBSD, NetBSD and OpenBSD).
  • Solaris: any Sun Solaris operating system (further restrictions apply).
  • Java: any operating system with a Java Virtual Machine installed (Sun supports Linux , Windows and Solaris, but third-party vendors offer it to other operating systems).
  • other: I would not believe that there are still people coding software for OS/2 and BeOS, but it is true.
If you are not a computer expert, do not mind the license. If you are interested though, most software is in BSD (no limitations at all), GPL (can not change the license or compile with other license software, among other restrictions), or somewhere in between (LGPL, EPL, MPL, etc).

The List

The software in this list is software which I use or used, and that I recommend trying, as a nice alternative to proprietary (and usually illegal!) software that you use. It has been on my GNOME desktop for too long. It is time to share it (I need the space).

Web

Firefox Web browser. Linux, OS X, Win32 MPL/GPL/LGPL
Firestarter Firewall graphical frontend. Linux GPL
Gaim Chat client for MSN, IRC, Yahoo, GoogleTalk... Linux, OS X, Win32 GPL
LFTP Text-mode FTP client. Linux GPL
SeaMonkey (âMozilla suiteâ) Web suite. Linux, OS X, Win32 MPL/GPL/LGPL
Sunbird Calendar application. Linux, OS X, Win32 MPL/GPL/LGPL
Thunderbird Email client. Linux, OS X, Win32 MPL/GPL/LGPL


Software Development

Multimedia

Games

entry.title: Java 6 and OOo 2.1
entry.content:
This December is becoming a nice month for open-source geeks: Java 6 and OpenOffice.org 2.1 have been released.

Java 6

The latest version of Java has been released. Java 6 (or 1.6 for the old school guys ;)) biggest changes is not in the programming language or in the virtual machine technology, but in its license (as far as can tell from the release notes, it's mostly just an update). As of this release, Java is free software, namely GNU Public License (GPL). Sun had already given a great step forward by releasing Java 5 under open-source code (among many other software, such as the Solaris operating system and the NetBeans integrated development environment). However, the restrictive license prevented the FOSS community from taking advantage of the source access. The greatest loss was for the GNU/Linux community, which could not distribute Java with the operating system due to licenses incompatibility (which meant that they distribute the GNU Java VM/compiler, which wasn't all that great...). From now on, they can distribute Java, and more, it is possible to include the virtual machine in the Linux kernel may greatly improve Java applications' performance (as it happens in Solaris).

OpenOffice.org 2.1

Well, nothing much to say here. The OOo developers just added a couple of new features of which the only particularly exciting is an upgrade mechanism (cool, if it works on Linux as Firefox and Thunderbird upgrades do). Oh, and you can use multiple monitors on Impress, which can be nice for presentations.

Until next time, may you enjoy new and open software.

A real treat for Warsies, which I'm not (everybody knows that Star Trek is better than Star Wars [and everybody knows that Picard beats Kirk!]). Anyway, it is cool. entry.title: The Queen of the Damned
entry.content:
After six thousand years of horrifying stillness, Akasha, mother of all vampires and Queen of the Damned, has risen from her sleep to let loose the powers of the night.


The vampire chronicles continue

This third book directly continues the second book (see my post), so this is a must after reading/buying the 'Vampire Lestat'. However, unlike the previous books which were centered in the tale of one character (Louis and Lestat, respectively), this one has a different structure. We start of with an introduction by Lestat and then we are presented with the background story of most characters in the book (most of them appeared or are mentioned in the previous books). Finally, the action continues with Lestat after encountering Akasha and the remaining characters as they are told yet another tale.
This book is very nice, as you get to see lots of characters from various places and times all together at the same time. And as a bonus, you get a deeper understanding of Anne Rice's universe: new vampire powers, the vampire origin (which was hinted in the second book, but was not fully confirmed) and the existence of witchcraft (which is a source for some of Anne Rice's books).

Film vs. Book

Unlike "Interview with the Vampire", the "Queen of the Damned" film is quite different from the book. The first (obvious) difference is that the movie condenses the second and third book (since you need the second to understand the third), which is a big mistake. Telling the book in a movie would be complicated, telling two books was insane: most of the historical and mythological story is lost. While there are comprehensible differences between book and movie (as these two have different structures and timing), there are some which are quite bad: Akasha's immunity to the sun, the flight ability that every vampire has, the romantic relation between Jesse and Lestat, etc.
Having sad that, the film is not a complete loss. It is entertaining, and the fact that they adapted the 80's rock to 90's metal was a very nice move. It is not as good as the first movie, but it's worth the popcorn :)

I have just bought "Pandora" (New Tales of the Vampires), but I am unsure if I'm going to wait until finishing the Vampires Chronicles (seven books to go...).

Until next time, may you enjoy waking up the dead.

entry.title: Firefox 2.0: Rediscover the Web. Again.
entry.content:
The new major version of Firefox was released just last week.




Why Firefox?

Well, I wrote a nice post about it last year, when version 1.5 was released. Since it is in Portuguese I should write it again, but I'm feeling lazy. Here are some reasons why you should use it as your web browser:
  • It's free (as in free speech, not as in free beer);
  • It's light-weight, that is, relatively small (under 10 MB download) and fast;
  • It's for everyone (both in operating system as in language);
  • It's extensible (through the use of extensions/add-ons);
  • It's secure (not only by its features, but especially because it is not inside your operating system);
  • It's standard compliant (well, not completely, but it tries a lot harder than the competition).

A brand new Firefox in my Ubuntu 5.10 desktop

New Features in 2.0

Lets take a look at each of the announced new features:
  • Visual refresh: Yes, it's nice, but that's not very important to me.
  • Built-in phishing protection: I have to try it, but usually being alert should be enough (see this post). I guess this is a feature to rival with the new version of IE.
  • Enhanced search capabilities: Finally I can remove search engines without having to find the Firefox's search directory and delete the files manually.
  • Improved tabbed browsing: Nothing very new here, but these small improvements help ensuring a nice web experience.
  • Resuming your browsing session: Yes! I have been missing this feature since I changed from Opera to Firefox.
  • Previewing and subscribing to Web feeds: I'm not a big fan of feeds, so I have no comment about this.
  • Inline spell checking: Nice feature, uses the same engine as Thunderbird. I am using right know as I am writing this post. Quite better than Blogger's spell check, which keeps screwing my Unicode characters.
  • Live Titles: (see web feeds)
  • Improved Add-ons manager: Its nice that themes and add-ons are now together, but it is not very different. Just don't understand why the naming change from "extension" to "add-on", they should just call it "plug-ins".
  • JavaScript 1.7: Nice, a real new Web feature. But it would be a lot better if they would just finish the CSS 2 implementation.
  • Extended search plugin format: Didn't try these new engines.
  • Updates to the extension system: Under the hood changes. Never had any problem with extensions anyway (at least, using the official builds of Fx).
  • Client-side session and persistent storage: Same as above.
  • SVG text: Interesting, I have to try it someday.
  • New Windows installer: Don't know, I have just installed the Linux version, I have to try the Windows one later. I have been seeing this installation engine on various GPL applications (Gaim, for instance) lately though.
In the end...

The new Fx version adds some interesting features. Nevertheless, it is not a must have upgrade: if you are happy with Fx 1.x or 1.5.x, just keep with it. I'm only upgrading it because new extensions will be probably made only for 2.x (at least, that's what happened from 1.x to 1.5.x). That, and I am big fan of Firefox :)

Until next time, may you enjoy rediscovering the web. Again.

entry.title: The Battle for Wesnoth
entry.content:
The Battle for Wesnoth is a free turn-based strategy/role play game.


Wesnoth is a free (GPL licensed) game, one of few that have a professional look (along with Planeshift, for example). It is not 3D, as most commercial games are now, but rather good to play. Those of you who played games from the "Heroes Of Might And Magic" series will probably enjoy the game.
The game is available for a wide range of platforms: GNU/Linux, Windows, MacOSX, BeOS, Solaris, FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, AmigaOS4, OS/2 & eComStation (wow!); and in 20 different languages. It features both campaign (single player) and multi player modes. It is also possible to download new maps and campaigns from the web, inside the game.
I've been playing the 1.0.2 version for GNU/Linux (Fedora Core 4 build) and it's quite stable. The system requirements for x86 are not very demanding (Pentium II @ 400 MHz and 128 MB of RAM), but then again the game is simple in graphical terms. On the other hand, the strategy behind the game is not simple, it takes some hours of game play to understand the subtleties in it.
So, if like simple, but addictive games, like in the MS-DOS old-school days, give a try!

Until next time, may you enjoy strategy battles.

entry.title: The Vampire Lestat
entry.content:
'Ah, the taste and feel of blood when all passion and greed is sharpened in that one desire!'

I have just finished reading the book "The Vampire Lestat", by Anne Rice.



Vampire Chronicles

This book is the second of the Vampire Chronicles, a series of books written on the theme of vampires. It is the sequel of "Interview With The Vampire" and a prequel to "Queen Of The Dammed", both of which were adapted into film, in 1994 and 2002, respectively.
The book tells the story of Lestat, one of the main characters of the storyline. Lestat is the creator of Louis, the author of the interview. Lestat's story is quite more interesting that Louis', since it involves much more characters, places and stories. It also explains the background of the interview's events and well as lays the foundations of the later books.
I have read the first book (translated in to Portuguese) a couple of years ago, and I have found it quite fascinating, even for a book which I had already seen the film adaption (something rare). So, I have recently acquired the English edition second and third books, and after reading Lestat, I am looking for to having all the collection! That may take a while, since there 10 books for the Vampire Chronicles, 2 for the New Tales of the Vampires and 3 for the Lives of The Mayfair Witches (a series on witches, related with the vampire tales).

Between Hell and the Gene

Anne Rice's fictional vampiric world is quite fascinating. You see, most vampiric tales (specially in movies) fall in one of two categories: demons or mutants.
The classic tales (such as Dracula - which is nevertheless a great movie) represent vampires as demons, evil creatures that predate humans with no passion or remorse, only to be slayed by a hero. They run away from crosses and holy water, for they can't stand God. Also, they turn into dust when they die, which is usually with a stake in the heart (and consequent turning into dust).
On the other hand, the modern tales (such as Blade) represent vampires as mutants, humans that mutated or evoluted into powerful creatures but can't stand the solar radiation and require human blood, for their blood insufficiency.
Rice's vampires are quite different. No stakes through the heart, no crucifixes, no holy water, no turning into dust, no count Dracula or Transylvania, no bats, no slayers or hunters, no heroes, no conspiracies, no experiments... She does not justified them either by religion or genetics, they just exist. In a certain way, the world is very atheist (since religion is very contested through the chronicles), but at the same time there is a certain mysticism which remains unexplained. Also, she does not ignore popular culture, instead explaining why such myths exist. And the characters are quite interesting: some passionate, some tormented... all of them very human in their emotions. I could write for hours about this world, but you really have to read it by yourself.

Until next time, may you enjoy tales of passion from blood sucking creatures.

entry.title: Engineer
entry.content:
Yes, since last Thursday, I'm an Computer Science Engineer (or a Computer Science BSc, for the non-Portuguese). What does that mean? Well, according to Wikipedia:
An engineer is someone who practices the profession of engineering. Engineers use creativity, technology, and scientific knowledge to solve practical problems.
Yes, that is what I'll do (hopefully) in a near future.

Graduation Presentation

My graduation presentation was very interesting, since I got to present it to a small audience: a three member "jury" and some colleagues at CAÂ³ (usually this only happens at MSc's, but my orientatior did it anyway). Also, I got to present it in same day as three of my colleagues at CAÂ³: AndrÃ© Marques, Tiago Fonseca and Bruno Miranda.
It went nice, although I did get a littnervousous (and some improvise didn't went that well :)). On friend Murphy was there when my Linux distro didn't work with the projector, but I had the software I needed in Windows too (OpenOffice.org, Firefox and JDK) [Editor's note: after the presentation I rebooted the computer in Linux, and it did work...].

me (with my best clothes), Bruno, Tiago and AndrÃ©

Graduation Report

The report was produced during the internship, but the final weeks were (naturally) the most productive. After working for months MS MS Office, I got the change to grokk OpenOffice.org. The hard part was the conversion of tMS MS DOC template (it would be easier to start from scratch...), but I got to do most I've wanted to: general index, table index, figure index, bibliography, page numbering, footers, etc. In general, I believe OOo is a very mature tool, both in features as in stability (well, except for the Fedora Core build - it was very buggy, try the official Linux build - it's stable and simple to install). Nevertheless, it needs some work on interface, namely on navigability (where's the damn "back" button for links?), PDF generation (tables don't look that good and the file size could be a little smaller), styles (some formatting I had to do it manually) and picture display (had to put page breaks for big pictures, or else they would sometimes overlap each other).
The outcome of my work through these six months is here for your viewing pleasure.

CAÂ³ and the future

Although my internshipship is over, I was invited (and accepted) to stay on more month at CAÂ³/FFCT, for writing an article (based in the developments on my internship) and some other tasks. I look forward to have some publication with my name :) After that, only time will tell. Anyway, I had a great experience here at CAÂ³, I can only wish the best for the people that I've worked with!
Finally I leave you with yet another group picture, possibly the last one for me at CAÂ³. It was taken at a small celebration, after all of us have made the presentation.

Boys: AntÃ³nio FalcÃ£o, (prof.) Pedro Guerreiro, AndrÃ© Marques, Bruno Miranda, Tiago Fonseca, Ricardo Ferreira and Ricardo Raminhos; Girls: (prof.) Ana Moreira, Rita Ribeiro and Jasna KovaÄeviÄ

(Photos courtesy Jasna KovaÄeviÄ)

Until next time, may you have the joy of ending a cycle in your life.

entry.title: The Great Dictator
entry.content:
Tonight I bring you a text. This was written and interpreted by Charles Chaplin in the 1940 movie, The Great Dictator. It is a very beautiful text, and I believe it is timeless. I discovered it through a sample in Timo Tolkki's track "Hymn To Life".

I'm sorry but I don't want to be an Emperor - that's not my business - I don't want to rule or conquer anyone. I should like to help everyone if possible, Jew, gentile, black man, white. We all want to help one another, human beings are like that.
We want to live by each other's happiness, not by each other's misery. We don't want to hate and despise one another. In this world there is room for everyone and the good earth is rich and can provide for everyone.
The way of life can be free and beautiful.
But we have lost the way.
Greed has poisoned men's souls - has barricaded the world with hate; has goose-stepped us into misery and bloodshed.
We have developed speed but we have shut ourselves in: machinery that gives abundance has left us in want. Our knowledge has made us cynical, our cleverness hard and unkind. We think too much and feel too little: More than machinery we need humanity; More than cleverness we need kindness and gentleness. Without these qualities, life will be violent and all will be lost.
The aeroplane and the radio have brought us closer together. The very nature of these inventions cries out for the goodness in men, cries out for universal brotherhood for the unity of us all. Even now my voice is reaching millions throughout the world, millions of despairing men, women and little children, victims of a system that makes men torture and imprison innocent people. To those who can hear me I say Do not despair.
The misery that is now upon us is but the passing of greed, the bitterness of men who fear the way of human progress: the hate of men will pass and dictators die, and the power they took from the people, will return to the people and so long as men die, liberty will never perish...
Soldiers - don't give yourselves to brutes, men who despise you, enslave you - who regiment your lives, tell you what to do, what to think and what to feel, who drill you, diet you, treat you like cattle, use you as cannon fodder!
Don't give yourselves to these unnatural men, machine men, with machine minds and machine hearts! You are not machines! You are not cattle! You are men! You have the love of humanity in your hearts. You don't hate - only the unloved hate - the unloved and the unnatural. Soldiers - don't fight for slavery, fight for liberty!
In the seventeenth chapter of Saint Luke it is written the kingdom of God is within man - not one man, nor a group of men - but in all men - in you! You the people have the power, the power to create machines, the power to create happiness! You the people have the power to make this life free and beautiful, to make this life a wonderful adventure! Then in the name of democracy let us use that power - let us all unite!!! Let us fight for a new world, a decent world that will give men a chance to work, that will give you the future and old age and security. By the promise of these things, brutes have risen to
power, but they lie! They do not fulfil their promise, they never will! Dictators free themselves but they enslave the people! Now let us fight to fulfil that promise! Let us fight to free the world, to do away with national barriers, to do away with greed, with hate and intolerance! Let us fight for a world of reason, a world where science and progress will lead to all men's happiness.
Soldiers - in the name of democracy, let us all unite!!!

Until next time, may you enjoy life.

entry.title: CGD scam
entry.content:
Caros,

Anda por aÃ­ mais um internet "scam". AlguÃ©m anda a enviar um mail em nome da Caixa Geral de DepÃ³sitos, a pedir Ã s pessoas que usam o CGD online para re-introduzir os seus dados. NÃ£o o faÃ§am.

O texto Ã© algo do gÃ©nero:

Cliente respeitado!

Devido a situaÃ§Ã£o que nÃ³s temos em nosso paÃ­s em torno a Online-Banking, nÃ³s fazemos exame de medidas para rever todas as contas-online a fim de descobrir as contas de "um dia", utilizadas para "lavagem" do dinheiro roubado. NÃ³s pedimos a todos os clientes encher o formulÃ¡rio da confirmaÃ§Ã£o dos dados da conta.

AtenÃ§Ã£o! As contas que nÃ£o passarÃ£o a revisÃ£o a 30.08.06, serÃ£o restritas Ã  explanaÃ§Ã£o a fim de seu abertura e uso. A revisÃ£o atual Ã© requerida para os clientes particulares e para as empresas.

Este tipo de mails, sÃ£o geralmente fÃ¡ceis de identificar, desde que se esteja atento e tenha atenÃ§Ã£o a alguns pormenores. Algumas pistas do que o mail era falso:
  • se existisse de facto um problema de seguranÃ§a, a CGD mandaria uma carta para casa das pessoas, o email nÃ£o Ã© um meio fiÃ¡vel, alÃ©m de anunciar na pÃ¡gina principal;

  • os links que aparecem escritos como da caixa na verdade vÃ£o para outras localizaÃ§Ãµes (nÃ£o Ã© visÃ­vel aqui porque sÃ³ o copiei o texto e nÃ£o o cÃ³digo HTML);

entry.title: CAÂ³: Meet the team
entry.content:
Today I've decided to write something a little different from the usual monthly (late) report. I'm going to introduce the people that work currently at CAÂ³. Since this team is constantly changing, this is going to be for posterity. Note that I'm only going to introduce the team that works with me everyday.

AndrÃ© Marques

AndrÃ© is my project colleague, and he is doing his BSc project internship, as I am. Although we did entered the degree in the same year, we've just met at CAÂ³. AndrÃ© is known for his abilities regarding crickets and he does look a lot like the napster guy (he uses a short hair cut and big head phones :)).

AntÃ³nio FalcÃ£o

AntÃ³nio is the eldest member of CAÂ³, so he is part of the backbone of the group. He works in lots of projects, keeps the records of the meetings, maintains the web site and still goes to meetings and conferences on behalf of the group(!). On the other hand he always takes a long time eating his lunch (everybody waits for him). He's an old school computer guy, so he's the only one I known that doesn't use MSN (he uses ICQ instead).

Bruno Miranda

Bruno is also doing his BSc project internship. His project is a cross-cutting project, so he's working with two teams at the same time. His dream is to pilot airplanes, so he's a really expert on the subject. However, he is quite paranoid: although he works for ESA, he doesn't believe mankind has ever been to the moon.

Jasna Kovacevic

Jasna is a servian PhD student. While she doesn't start her thesis (something about fuzzy and aspects), she is doing a little warm-up in our project. Although she knows how to talk portuguese, she refuses to talk with us in portuguese, due to our slang over-use :)

Paulo Serra

Paulo is only non-computer science guy. He is the math guy, an expert on fuzzy logic. Luckly for him, he only works part-time in CAÂ³, or else he would be crazy by now, trying to understand our insane sense of humour. He will leave us very soon, going for a MSc somewhere in the Netherlands.

Pedro Tiago Fonseca

Tiago is also working on his BSc intership. His expertise is in networks and he trying to attend a course for Cisco. Also, as well as Bruno, he has several theories on women behaviour.

Ricardo Ferreira

Ferreira is working on his MSc project. He is also my external coordinator in my project. He's the only left wing guy besides me at CAÂ³, and likes punk and trance music. On the other hand, he prefers .NET to Java. Besides that, he has this strange obsession with the theme song of "Neverending Story" and adding the "ens" and "ster" suffixes to random words (e.g. "Tomcat" becomes "Tomcatster").

Ricardo Raminhos

Raminhos is working on his MSc project with Ferreira. Also, as Ferreira, he is part of my project management and AndrÃ©'s external coordinator. Raminhos a natural leader, the guy that saves the day at meetings, just in time before everybody starts hitting each other. Also, he has quite a bad sense of humour, much like mine! He is also preparing for a nuclear holocaust, for he has a huge amount of water, milk and cookies, stored next to his desk.


From left to right: AntÃ³nio, Raminhos, Jasna, me, Bruno, Ferreira, Tiago and Rui
Photo courtesy of AntÃ³nio FalcÃ£o

Until next time, may you enjoy meeting new people.

A few days ago I had some problems with my area and had to delete everything in my web space, so my home page as been offline. This is actually a good thing, because I'll force myself to rebuild my home page from scratch (something I've been wanting to do for some time, but having been too lazy to do it). It's going to be called Caleb v42 (why? try to guess...) and will have little content, but it will be (hopefully) more useful.

Until next time, may you have time for rethinking your life.

entry.title: Super Bock Super Rock 2006
entry.content:
This week started the Super Bock Super Rock 2006 festival.

The Festival

For the non-Portuguese, Super Bock Super Bock is a summer music festival, sponsored by a know beer brand. This year's edition it was a four day festival, divided in two acts, in Lisbon (Parque do Tejo). I was in the first day of the first act. The line-up for the main stage was: Ramp, Moonspell, Soulfly, Within Temptation and Korn.

Ramp

Since we were late for the festival, we completely missed this concert. Although I don't know much of the band's discography, I did watched them live, a few years ago in the T99 festival.

Moonspell

The worst thing about losing the first concert was almost losing the second one. Yes, the line at the festival was so big, that we've lost most of the Moonspell concert. It was a real pity, because I really like them. Again, I did watched them live, a few years ago in Barreiro. This time we got to listen two songs, one from their new album and "Full Moon Madness".




Soulfly

Although I've used to listen to them a few years ago, I really haven't listened to their latest two albums. Surprisingly the concert was really good, possibly the best performance of the day. They really shaked the place, everybody was jumping and having a great time. Their live performance was really hardcore, sometimes playing four and five songs in a really fast medley. They played some old tracks, such as "Eye For An Eye" and "Back To The Primitive", and some even older Sepultura tracks, such as "Roots" and "Refuse/Resist". As Max Cavalera said, "Bota pra foder!"






Within Temptation

This is one of my favourite bands at the time, and I've been really looking forward for watching them live, since this is the third time they come to Portugal (2002, as the opening band for Paradise Lost; 2005, in a summer festival, with Nightwish), and I both times I couldn't go. This time, there was no excuse! The concert was pretty cool, with the expected props and songs. Most of the songs were from "The Silent Force" (which was no surprise, since this is their best selling album) and "Mother Earth". For our delight, they still played two old tracks: "Candles" (from the "Enter" album) and "The Other Half (Of Me)" (from the "The Dance" EP). Nice to see they can still do grunts (6)! The concert was just awesome, and people were really enjoying without problems (we were very close to the stage, and there was no violence).










Korn

I confess I don't know that much songs about Korn, so I had no expectations. The concert was ok, although the band didn't really communicate with the audience (as Moonspell and Within Temptation did). Anyway, they still played two songs I know: "Falling Away From Me" and "A.D.I.D.A.S. (All Day I Dream About Sex)".

The Organization

The place was ok, although the line was huge to get in. The police officers were really with a "caustic" attitude (the old stereotype about metal fans using drugs and violence is still present...). The word was that the beer really sucked (I don't know, since I don't drink alcohol), but the Kellogg's stand really saved the day with the cereals and milk offer :) There were lots of other stands, but with all the concerts (ten, five in each stage), there was really no time to see them.



Until next time, may you enjoy rocking.

entry.title: CAÂ³: Second Month
entry.content:
Another month has passed, and here I am to report the project's progress.

A new task

For my graduation project, the planning was for two tasks. The first one is to perform a re-analysis of a case study, using an aspect oriented methodology. The second one is to perform an analysis for a set of client tools of a support system for that kind of analysis. Well, my coordinator decided that it wasn't enough, so I now have a third task: to program part of that client tools. In a certain way I'm happy because pure analysis without coding isn't all that fun to me, and also I like coding in Java (and getting more experience in Swing is a bonus). On the other hand, extra work is always bad, but mostly I will be performing three tasks in parallel, when then should be done in sequence.

Software

After a little adaptation time, I've been really enjoying using Eclipse. It has some cool features, such as: built-in CVS support, code conventions enforcing (quite in handy, since ESA has a 100+ page document on Java code conventions...), refactoring, getters/setters generation, a package import resolution.
Also, I've started using ArgoUML (yeah!) for state machine and class diagrams.

A new carbon unit

A carbon unit is the nice name we have for a human resource (AKA "a person"). The last person of the project (the coder, has arrived and started working this week). The team is full!

Future Work

Finishing the all three tasks :) Coding, analysing and writing (lots) of documents!

From left to right:
AntÃ³nio, Ferreira, Miranda, AndrÃ©, me (!), Ivan (physics scientist from Slovakia), Alexei (MSc student from Russia), Paulo (math guy) and Raminhos

Until next time, may you enjoy the second month.

Photo courtesy of Ivan DorotoviÄ.

entry.title: The Moral Animal
entry.content:
"The Moral Animal" is a book written by Robert Wright, that I've just finished reading this week.



What is this book about

This book is about evolutionary psychology. Putting it simply, evolutionary psychology proposes to understand human behaviour in terms of evolution. While "classical" psychology tries to understand behaviour in terms of the individual's past, evolutionary psychology tries to do it in terms of species past. This science is based on Darwin's ideas and interesting enough (at least for me) uses a computational model to study behaviour.
For people who are familiar with the subject, this book is recommended by persons such as Steven Pinker and Richard Dawkins.

Motivation

While I'm no expert in psychology, this area is very interesting for me, both in the underlying computational model, but also in the social and political implications of this science's work. I've heard about this book last year, while I was attending the ComputaÃ§Ã£o e CiÃªncias Cognitivas (Computing and Cognitive Sciences) course, which was taught by LuÃ­s Moniz Pereira (which by the way, is the Portuguese scientist with more published papers internationally, and also a very interesting person to have a talk to).

My opinion

The book is very interesting, especially because the case study that the author used to explain some ideas was none other than Charles Darwin. In one the final chapters there is an interesting comparision between Freud's and (modern) Darwinism ideas. Last, but no least, the author acknowledges that evolutionary psychology has some trouble explaining some behaviours (homosexuality, suicide, war sacrifices, etc) and writes something about it, namely some possible solutions and future work.
On the other hand, there was something that was missing from the book: the meme theory. I'm not sure if the author disagrees with it, or is simply ignorant on the subject, but I do feel that it would be an interesting paradigm that could shed some light on some of the problems he discusses.

Until next time, may you read interesting books.

entry.title: CAÂ³: First Month
entry.content:
My BSc Project started over a month. I'm going to talk a little bit about its progress.

Finally my name is written in a door!

My Work

Well, after the initial study, which involved reading many scientific papers, I have finally started doing something. Mostly writing reports, but this week I've started my analysis (the reason I'm there - to analyse!). I've also done a little presentation with my colleague, about the case study system (something I don't like doing, but I have to).

Technologies

On one of the documents I'm writing I have been explaining the technology which we'll be using, so I've been revisiting lots of XML stuff (XML Schema, XSLT, XPath...), and getting to know so new ones to (XQuery, Schematron, SOAP...). Also, I've been using eXist (an XML native DBMS) and Apache Tomcat (a Web Server with servlets and JSP).

Software

I have been using Eclipse for some code tests. Very interesting, I tell you. Its a very nice IDE, with lots of frameworks and plugins.
As sad as it may be, I'm using lots of MS software: Windows 2000, Office 2000 and Visio. Also, I've been using OpenOffice.org 2.0, for non-official documents (the full interoperability with MS Office is still a dream). I've noticed some interesting things. MS Office is much faster loading big DOCs (pictures are loaded on demand), but on the other hand it consumes a constant rate of 50% CPU usage (it's not 100% because it's an Intel CPU with Hyperthreading). Don't ask me why!

Future Work

(Sorry, I'm reading to much papers!) Well, soon my second colleague (Jasna) will arrive, and since she's the programmer, we will have to hurry up on our analysis. I will also have to finish my technology analysis in order to know which libraries will be used. Later, I'll make some mock-ups using SWT (the closest thing to coding I'll ever do in this project).

People

Great people at CA3, it looks like I have know them for years. Every time there is a birthday, there is celebration. That, and it's a geek heaven :)
AndrÃ© and me
Until next time, may you have a first month.
Photos courtesy of AndrÃ© Marques.

entry.title: The Beginning Is The End Is The Beginning
entry.content:
In this post I present a few changes in this blog...

Yet Another Presentation

Hi, my name is SÃ©rgio Agostinho (AKA: âCalebâ) and this is my weblog. Currently I'm an undergraduate student in a BSc in computer engineering at FCT-UNL and a research engineer at UNINOVA (at least for my BSc project). On my free(?) time I'm a developer for the ArgoUML project and play Magic: the Gathering, among other very interesting things.

For those of you who already know my blog, you might be wondering why is this post in English...

English, please!


Well, as long as I'm working at CA3 (UNINOVA) I have to write reports directed to ESA, and therefore in English. Besides that, most computer science/engineering books and documentation are written in English, so this seems like a good opportunity to improve my English. (And the fact that English is the de facto international language helps too!)

Although my objective is to write in British English, the truth is that most vocabulary I have comes from American culture (movies, games, books, etc), so the result might be something in between. And I make lots of mistakes. My apologies to those whose English is their mother tongue!


How about Portuguese?

Although English will be the default language for the blog, I will leave it as bilingual site, because some posts will only make sense for Portuguese speaking persons. You might be thinking if writing this blog in English won't ostracise the Portuguese speaking persons. Yes, it might â but so does writing about computers, and that's what I've done since the start. It's a risk I'm willing to take.

Not just computers

Here is the funny part: now I've decided not to talk only about computers . Why? Because I write about them most of my time: in my course, in my work, in my past work... I think that's enough! So, what will I write about? Just about anything I feel like to: books, music, MtG (yes, some of you might have been fearing it for some time), movies, whatever!

Until next time, may you change some things in your live. (And yes, I'm imitating this guy)

entry.title: Projecto de Final de Curso

Apesar de ser uma trabalho muito teÃ³rico, trata-se de algo extremamente interessante, pois Ã© uma Ã rea relativamente pouco explorada. Quem sabe se daqui a uma dÃ©cada o desenvolvimento orientado por aspectos nÃ£o serÃ¡ tÃ£o mainstream como o orientado por objectos Ã© hoje?

entry.title: GNU ou Linux: eis a questÃ£o
entry.content:
Muitas vezes se usa o termo "Linux" e algumas vezes o termo "GNU/Linux" (como por exemplo no meu blog). Qual a diferenÃ§a e o que Ã© que cada um significa? Vou responder a essas e muitas mais questÃµes. Ou entÃ£o nÃ£o.

O sistema GNU



O projecto GNU (GNU's Not Unix) comeÃ§ou em 1984 com o objectivo de criar um sistema operativo baseado em Unix, completamente livre. O trabalho (liderado por Richard Stallman) comeÃ§ou antes e no inicio dos anos 90 estava quase completo, mas um dos componentes principais do sistema GNU, o nÃºcleo (kernel) HURD estava longe de completo...

O nÃºcleo Linux



... Entretanto, em 1991, um estudante finlandÃªs Linus Torvalds estava a trabalhar com sistema Minix, um sistema Unix simplificado, usado para fins pedagÃ³gicos. Como este era um sistema como uma licenÃ§a muito limitada, nÃ£o era possÃ­vel extender, pelo que Torvalds decidiu criar um de raÃ­z...

O duo dinÃ¢mico



... AtÃ© que membros do GNU e o Linus Torvalds se encontraram numa conferÃªncia e decidiram adaptar o kernel Ã s ferramentas GNU e as ferramentas GNU ao kernel. Foi usada a licenÃ§a GPL (GNU General Public License) e o Linus comeÃ§ou a distribuir ambos pela Internet no final de 1991. Pouco depois, vÃ¡rios entusiastas na Net comeÃ§aram a trabalhar no cÃ³digo e rapidamente a explosÃ£o comeÃ§ou. Seguindo a sugestÃ£o de um colega, o Linus chamou ao sistema Linux. Pouco depois, a cisÃ£o entre o Torvalds e Stallman comeÃ§ou, porque o projecto GNU defende que se chame ao sistema GNU/Linux. AtÃ© hoje, a discussÃ£o persiste.

A cisÃ£o

O projecto GNU defende o termo GNU/Linux, porque foram eles que comeÃ§aram o projecto do sistema e foram eles que tiveram a maior parte do trabalho. O projecto GNU defende o software livre acima de tudo e crÃª que o nome deveria dar crÃ©dito a essa filosofia que eles tanto defendem (e que tÃ£o mal compreendida Ã©). Chamar ao sistema Linux Ã© sinÃ³mino Ã© como dizer que o sistema operativo foi feito por uma Ãºnica pessoa, Linus Torvalds.

Por outro lado, a maior parte das pessoas usa o termo Linux, porque foi o termo popularizado desde cedo. Ã bem mais fÃ¡cil e simples de dizer. Num sistema Linux encontra-se o trabalho de diversas pessoas e grupos, alÃ©m do GNU e do Linus e ninguÃ©m quer chamar ao sistema GNU/Linux/X/Apache/MySQL/PHP/Mozilla... AlÃ©m disso, Ã© teoricamente possÃ­vel fazer um sistema Linux sem nenhuma ferramenta GNU.

Afinal o que Ã© um sistema operativo?

Bom, alguns de vocÃªs pensarÃ£o: "mas afinal o que Ã© um sistema operativo? deve haver uma definiÃ§Ã£o!...". Bom, infelizmente nÃ£o existe sequer uma definiÃ§Ã£o tÃ©cnica consensual do que Ã© um Sistema Operativo. Algumas pessoas definem um sistema operativo como o kernel, uma vez que Ã© onde estÃ£o as funcionalidades fulcrais. Outras pessoas definem um sistema operativo como todo o software que Ã© distribuÃ­do no CD/DVD/diskette.

Embora a primeira definiÃ§Ã£o seja mais palpÃ¡vel, a verdade Ã© que nÃ£o se faz nada sÃ³ com um kernel. Por outro lado, a segunda definiÃ§Ã£o Ã© demasiado extensiva, pois o CD de distribuiÃ§Ã£o pode vir o mais variado software. Infelizmente, nem eu nem ninguÃ©m consegue arranjar uma fronteira clara, pois existe sempre software que fica na zona cinzenta.

Na prÃ¡tica

Na prÃ¡tica, quase todas as distribuiÃ§Ã£o chamam ao sistema "Xpto Linux": Red Hat Linux, Fedora Core Linux, SUSE Linux, etc. Uma das poucas (notÃ¡veis) excepÃ§Ãµes Ã© Debian GNU/Linux, criado pelo projecto Debian, cuja filosofia tem muito em comum com o GNU, pelo que nÃ£o Ã© surpresa eles defenderem esta posiÃ§Ã£o. O problema Ã© que muitas vezes a maior parte das pessoas (especialmente a imprensa...) nÃ£o sabe a diferenÃ§a entre o Linux SO e o Linux kernel.

ConclusÃ£o?

Pessoalmente, creio que o termo "GNU/Linux" Ã© mais justo em termos histÃ³ricos, pois foi graÃ§as ao projecto GNU que o sistema foi criado e foi graÃ§as ao Linus Torvalds que o sistema se popularizou. Em termos tÃ©cnicos, jÃ¡ Ã© altura das pessoas perceberem que Linux Ã© um kernel e nÃ£o um sistema operativo (e que a ideia de um SO feito por uma Ãºnica pessoa Ã© absurda). Em termos filosÃ³ficos, creio que a conduta moral do Linus Torvalds Ã© bastante lastimÃ¡vel, pois - sem tirar o mÃ©rito que lhe Ã© devido - aproveitou o trabalho de muita gente para promover a sua carreira (que corre bastante bem, segundo consta).

Por outro lado, a verdade Ã© que o termo "Linux" Ã© bem mais sucinto, especialmente a nÃ­vel oral. Geralmente, quando se fala com alguÃ©m dentro da Ã rea Ã© fÃ¡cil perceber o significado atravÃ©s do contexto. O mesmo acontece noutros sistemas: "DOS" (MS-DOS), "Windows" (MS-Windows) e "OS X" (MacOS X). (Ã verdade que sÃ£o casos um pouco diferentes, pois a omissÃ£o Ã© da empresa que os criou, mas Ã© sÃ³ para ficarem com a ideia.)

Em que Ã© que ficamos? Bom, pessoalmente vou continuar a usar GNU/Linux em escrita e Linux em oral. Ao fim e ao cabo, creio que o mais importante nÃ£o Ã© nome, mas que se perceba a diferenÃ§a. Como disse alguÃ©m: "There are lots of people on this bus[...]. I recommend you be happy we have a bus."

AtÃ© breve e fiquem felizes com os autocarros que temos,

entry.title: SeguranÃ§a em Windows: alguns conselhos
entry.content:
Visto que se tem falado muito do vulnerabilidade WMF do Windows, aproveito para deixar algumas ideias de como tentar evitar problemas de seguranÃ§a no Windows.

Um sistema seguro

Bom, um sistema seguro Ã© aquele que estÃ¡ desligado da internet, nÃ£o tem drives e acima de tudo nÃ£o tem teclado, visto que Ã© entre a cadeira e o teclado que se encontra a maior vulnerabilidade dos computadores. Por outras palavras, nÃ£o existe seguranÃ§a absoluta, mas uma seguranÃ§a relativa. "A manivela da paranoia roda proporcionalmente Ã  quantidade de dinheiro envolvido", parafraseando um certo professor. Pode nÃ£o parecer fazer sentido falar em dinheiro quando se trata do PC de casa de alguÃ©m, mas lembrem-se que tempo Ã© dinheiro.

InstalaÃ§Ã£o

Uma das grandes novidades da familia de sistemas operativos Windows NT Ã© a possibilidade de uma mÃ¡quina ser infectada com vÃ­rus sem grande interacÃ§Ã£o do utilizador bastando que esteja ligada em rede (jÃ¡ me aconteceu apanhar o blaster entre a instalaÃ§Ã£o do Windows 2000 e o anti-vÃ­rus). Assim, o melhor Ã© fazer a instalaÃ§Ã£o do Windows e do software mÃ­nimo offline. A primeira coisa Ã  fazer Ã© instalar o Ãºltimo service pack para a versÃ£o/lÃ­ngua do Windows (nÃ£o deve ser muito dificil encontrar no site da Microsoft).

Anti-vÃ­rus

O anti-vÃ­rus Ã© uma ferramenta sempre util. Existem muitos no mercado: McAfee, Norton, etc (basta procurar). Todos tem uma versÃ£o de avaliaÃ§Ã£o de 30 dias, mas alguns atÃ© tÃªm uma versÃ£o gratuÃ­ta, como o AVG e o Avast!.

Firewall

Uma vez que a maior parte das ameÃ§as sÃ£o worms que se espalham pela rede aproveitando vulnerabilidades em serviÃ§os distribuÃ­dos, uma firewall Ã© indispensÃ¡vel. Embora as versÃµes mais recentes do Windows como XP jÃ¡ trazerem uma firewall, o melhor Ã© nÃ£o arriscar e instalar uma Ã  parte. Pessoalmente, tenho usado a Zone Alarm e estou satisfeito (tem uma versÃ£o gratuÃ­ta).

Spyware

Nos Ãºltimos anos outro problema crescente tem sido o spyware. Embora possa nÃ£o ser tÃ£o fatal como os vÃ­rus, consegue ser mais irritante. O melhor Ã© tambÃ©m ter uma ferramenta de detecÃ§Ã£o e remoÃ§Ã£o. Uso o Ad-Aware, embora tambÃ©m me tenham dito que o Spybot Ã© interessante.

Web Browser

Uma das maneiras mais comuns de infecÃ§Ã£o de vÃ­rus e especialmente spyware Ã© o web browser (leia-se o Internet Explorer). Uma vez que Ã© o browser mais usado e o facto de estar integrado no Windows tornam-no um alvo fÃ¡cil. O ActiveX e a mÃ¡quina virtual do Java da MS tambÃ©m sÃ£o conhecidas maneiras de explorar vulnerabilidades. O melhor Ã© utilizarem um outro browser. Pessoalmente recomendo o Mozilla suite e o Firefox (fiz um post sobre isso), embora o Opera e o Netscape possam ser alternativas interessantes.

Cliente de Email

Ainda outra maneira de explorar vulnerabilidades Ã© atravÃ©s do "bom" velho Outlook. O Thunderbird Ã© uma alternativa interessante da Mozilla Corporation. O email Ã© um dos grandes engarrafamentos da internet, graÃ§as ao SPAM comercial, domÃ©stico e criado por vÃ­rus.

Office

Outra maneira engenhosa de propagar vÃ­rus Ã© atravÃ©s das macros do MS Office, que podem estar associadas a um documento. Podem simplesmente desligar as funcionalidades de macro (a maior parte das pessoas nÃ£o precisa mesmo delas), ou entÃ£o mudar para o OpenOffice.org ;)

ActualizaÃ§Ãµes

TÃ£o importante como instalar o software Ã© mantÃª-lo actualizado. Devem fazer updates do Windows, anti-vÃ­rus e anti-spyware com bastante frequÃªncia. Regra geral esses programas atÃ© tÃªm uma funcionalidade de actualizaÃ§Ãµes automÃ¡ticas.

A raÃ­z de todo o mal

Ao contrÃ¡rio do que alguns dizem, a raÃ­z de todo o mal nÃ£o Ã© o Windows (embora eu possa aproveitar esta ocasiÃ£o para sugerir que usem um sistema GNU/Linux :)). Como disse no Ã­nicio, a maior vulnerabilidade Ã© mesmo o factor humano. O software pode ser bom ou mau, mas os utilizadores fazem toda a diferenÃ§a.

AtÃ© breve e boa seguranÃ§a,

entry.title: Coding Camp
entry.content:
No passado fim de semana deu-se o "Coding Camp" #1 da ervilhAzul.

O que Ã© um "coding camp"?

Trata-se um termo que eu inventei para designar o fenÃ³meno que ocorre quando trÃªs jovens informÃ¡ticos que decidem dormir, comer e trabalhar durante 3 dias seguidos na mesma casa de modo a completar trabalho atrasado (um novo significado para extreme programming?).

O Local

O local deste encontro Ã© a sede da ervilhAzul (que por mera coincidÃªncia Ã© a casa de umas das pessoas envolvidas). EstÃ¡ localizada algures na margem norte do rio Tejo, que por motivos de seguranÃ§a a localizaÃ§Ã£o exacta nÃ£o serÃ¡ revelada.

As pessoas

Aqui estÃ¡ o staff (por ordem de aparÃªncia):

  • Vitor: programador, analista, orÃ§amentista, administrador de sistema (AKA: "sysadmin") e gestor de projecto (AKA: "chefe");
  • JoÃ£o: programador (AKA: "coder"), analista e fumador;
  • SÃ©rgio: programador, analista (embora queira popularizar o termo "desenvolvedor"), documentador e (mau) fotÃ³grafo;
  • Joana: designer, treinadora de animais, cozinheira e (boa) fotÃ³grafa
Day 1

Objectivo: acabar um trabalho para a faculdade atÃ© Ã s 24:00.

O primeiro dia comeÃ§ou tarde (para variar), jÃ¡ depois da hora de almoÃ§o. ComeÃ§ou com os preparativos dos postos de trabalho e de dormida. De resto foi martelar no UML e OCL (amadiÃ§oando o Objecteering e o USE) atÃ© Ã s 23h50. Pelo meio uma refeiÃ§Ã£o de pizza e cola (um clÃ¡ssico!).

EstÃ¡s a olhar para onde?


"Pizza, the food of kings!"
- Homer Simpson

Day 2

Objectivo: projecto "mediateca".

O segundo dia comeÃ§a com a espera de um elemento que fugiu na noite anterior, enquanto batalhas Ã©picas do Battle for Wesnoth e The Mana World eram travadas. O dia foi marcado pelo brainstorm das Ãºltimas remodelaÃ§Ãµes na base de dados e pelas discussÃµes dos formulÃ¡rios/classes a fazer. A presenÃ§a do 4Âº elemento do grupo trouxe-nos refeiÃ§Ãµes equilibradas, mas tambÃ©m um cÃ£o raivoso que vigiava as pausas dos pobres programadores (o sindicato saberÃ¡ disto).

Pinguins! Pinguins!


Os postos de trabalho...

Day 3

Objectivo: projecto "webNews".

O terceiro dia trÃ¡s mais um brainstorm sobre outra base de dados e cÃ³digo a fazer. Os problemas tÃ©cnicos. Problemas tÃ©cnicos na ferramenta de modelaÃ§Ã£o dÃ£o-me dores de cabeÃ§a. O dia termina mais cedo, para descanso do pessoal.

Sleepy coder...


Tecla, tecla, que ele estÃ¡ a olhar!


ConclusÃµes

Em situaÃ§Ãµes como estas as pessoas conhecem-se mais, tanto para o melhor, como para o pior e atÃ© mesmo para o bizzarro. O sentido de humor e a mÃºsica (proporcionais Ã  fadiga) foram uma constante. Por outro lado, houve a mÃ¡ linguagem (mereÃ§o um prÃ©mio pelo meu rÃ¡cio de asneiras por linha de cÃ³digo) e os insultos a sistemas operativos e editores de texto de colegas (que em desenvolvimento de software podem ter proporÃ§Ãµes politicas e mesmo religiosas). Por fim, houve o bizarro como ver o que as outras pessoas comem, vestem como roupa interior e quantas vezes vÃ£o Ã  casa de banho por dia.

AtÃ© breve e boas experiÃªncias,

entry.title: Promessas para 2006

Um novo ano comeÃ§ou e nesta altura as pessoas fazem promessas que nÃ£o irÃ£o cumprir. Eu nÃ£o sou excepÃ§Ã£o.

TambÃ©m cheguei Ã  conclusÃ£o que escrever numa base semanal dÃ¡ mais trabalho do que parece. Em relaÃ§Ã£o Ã  lingua, de facto faria mais sentido escrever em inglÃªs devido Ã  internacionalizaÃ§Ã£o dos temas (tal como o Ricardo fez), mas a verdade Ã© que tambÃ©m nÃ£o acredito que exista assim tanta a gente a ler o blog :)

entry.title: Software Livre: confusÃµes frequentes
entry.content:
Muitas vezes vejo certos termos a serem mal usados na classificaÃ§Ã£o de software. Assim, decidi fazer aqui algumas classificaÃ§Ãµes de modo a esclarecer algumas confusÃµes frequentes. Note-se que estas definiÃ§Ãµes podem nÃ£o ser consensuais, sÃ£o as minhas interpretaÃ§Ãµes (simplificadas). Sempre que possÃ­vel vou incluir ligaÃ§Ãµes de pÃ¡ginas onde podem ser encontradas explicaÃ§Ãµes mais completas.

Software Comercial

Embora seja um termo muitas vezes usado, a verdade Ã© que a classificaÃ§Ã£o de software comercial Ã© muito vaga. Software comercial Ã© software que Ã© comercializado, ou seja, vendido, o que nÃ£o diz nada sobre a sua licenÃ§a, uma vez que tanto se pode comercializar software proprietÃ¡rio como livre (exemplo: a Red Hat comercializa software nÃ£o proprietÃ¡rio). Muitas vezes, quando se diz software comercial, quer-se dizer proprietÃ¡rio.

Software ProprietÃ¡rio

Software proprietÃ¡rio Ã© software que Ã© propriedade de alguÃ©m, ou seja, o uso de tal software estÃ¡ limitado no seu uso e distribuiÃ§Ã£o. Isto nÃ£o significa que seja sÃ³ software comercial (exemplo: Windows), mas tambÃ©m a software gratuito (exemplo: Internet Explorer). Assim, o software proprietÃ¡rio Ã© o oposto de software aberto, nÃ£o o oposto de software gratuito. A maior restriÃ§Ã£o do software proprietÃ¡rio Ã© o facto do cÃ³digo fonte nÃ£o ser do conhecimento dos utilizadores. Em termos de licenÃ§as, o software proprietÃ¡rio pode assumir vÃ¡rias formas: comercial, shareware, freeware, etc.

Software Aberto

O software aberto, geralmente designado por open-source, Ã© software aberto no sentido em que o cÃ³digo fonte estÃ¡ disponÃ­vel ao utilizador. A confusÃ£o tÃ­pica que se faz Ã© que open-source Ã© a mesma coisa que software livre, o que nÃ£o Ã© verdade. Todo o software livre Ã© aberto, mas nem todo o software aberto Ã© livre. O software aberto tem o cÃ³digo fonte disponÃ­vel, mas pode ter diversas restriÃ§Ãµes sobre o seu uso (por exemplo, a mÃ¡quina virtual do Java da Sun Ã© open-source, mas tem imensas restriÃ§Ãµes sobre a distribuiÃ§Ã£o). Para aumentar a confusÃ£o, muitas empresas (como a Red Hat, por exemplo), usam o termo aberto em detrimento do livre, por motivos de marketing (em inglÃªs, open-source soa melhor ao mercado empresarial que free software). Um dos grandes impulsionadores deste tipo de software (pelo menos desde 1998) Ã© a OSI (Open Source Initiative), um grupo que surgiu de uma cisÃ£o do projecto GNU.

Software Livre
Software livre Ã© software que nÃ£o tem limitaÃ§Ãµes tanto em termos de uso, como em termos de distribuiÃ§Ã£o. Isto significa que se pode fazer tudo sobre esse software... tudo, ou quase tudo (mais Ã  frente)! Tipicamente, existe uma enorme confusÃ£o entre software livre e gratuito, especialmente nas pessoas falantes de inglÃªs. "Free" Ã© uma palavra particularmente ambÃ­gua em inglÃªs, de modo a que geralmente surgem expressÃµes como "free as in beer" (gratuito) e "free as in free speech" (livre).
A maior divisÃ£o entre os apoiantes de software livre Ã© precisamente a definiÃ§Ã£o do que Ã© ser "livre". Desse problema surgiram as diferentes licenÃ§as de software livre. A universidade de Berkeley criou a licenÃ§a BSD para o seu sistema Berkeley Unix (vulgarmente tambÃ©m conhecido por BSD). Esta licenÃ§a permite que o software seja usado e distribuÃ­do sobre qualquer forma (com ou sem fins lucrativos), desde que seja mantido o aviso de copyright dos criadores do software.
Acontece que isto permite que a licenÃ§a possa ser modificada, inclusive de modo a tornar o software proprietÃ¡rio (como acontece por exemplo no programa 'ftp' que vem com os Windows da famÃ­la NT). Por este motivo, o projecto GNU ("GNU's Not Unix", uma sigla recursiva) criou uma licenÃ§a de sofware de "copyleft", que Ã© a mais usada neste momento (alegadamente 75% do software livre): o GPL (General Public License). O GPL impÃµe uma sÃ©rie de restriÃ§Ãµes de modo a tornar o software mais livre (ok, pode parecer um paradoxo, mas Ã© uma questÃ£o complexa...), nomeadamente o facto da licenÃ§a nÃ£o poder ser mudada. Assim, sempre que se distribuÃ­ um software GPL, Ã© obrigatÃ³rio passar todos os direitos que foram recebidos quando o recebemos. Assim, e seguindo a longa licenÃ§a GPL (confesso que nunca a li por completo, Ã© um pouco densa), surge por consequÃªncia outra restriÃ§Ã£o: o software GPL nÃ£o pode ser "misturado" que com software de outras licenÃ§as, mesmo que sejam livres. Como o prÃ³prio projecto GNU acabou por reconhecer, isto por vezes pode ser excessivamente limitativo e portanto foi criado o LGPL (Lesser General Public License). Embora, o GPL possa ser usado para qualquer coisa (mesmo fora do mundo do software), surgiu a necessidade de uma licenÃ§a mais especifica para a documentaÃ§Ã£o e assim apareceu o FDL (Free Documentation License).
Por fim, resta dizer que para aumentar a confusÃ£o existem mais licenÃ§as para alÃ©m do BSD e GNU. O projecto GNU tem uma lista de algumas e respectiva comparaÃ§Ã£o com as suas. TambÃ©m tem uma lista de categorias mais exaustiva de tipos de software.

AtÃ© breve!

entry.title: Firefox 1.5: redescubra a Web
entry.content:
A versÃ£o 1.5 do Firefox saÃ­u esta semana, pelo que me parece uma boa altura de falar do meu Web browser preferido.

Raposa Livre

O Firefox, tal como todo o software da Mozilla, Ã© software livre. Como tal, estÃ¡ disponÃ­vel para Windows, MacOS X e Linux (i686), numa grande quantidade de lÃ­nguas. Isto Ã©, as versÃµes oficiais, porque existem versÃµes modificadas por aÃ­ (para FreeBSD, por exemplo).

Keep It Simple

Uma das caracterÃ­sticas que gosto mais do Firefox (Fx para os amigos) Ã© a sua simplicidade. Ã pequeno (a instalaÃ§Ã£o para Windows Ã© 5 MB), rÃ¡pido e simples de usar, porque sÃ³ tem aquilo que Ã© mesmo preciso num browser.

Funcionalidades

O Fx tem todas as funcionalidades que se estÃ£o Ã  espera num browser moderno: tabbed browsing, pop-up blocking, motores de busca integrados, temas e extensÃµes. A minha funcionalidade preferida Ã© mesmo as extensÃµes que permitem extender o Fx Ã  medida das necessidades do utilizador. AlÃ©m disso, muitas delas sÃ£o independentes de plataforma, o que as torna particularmente atraentes para quem (como eu) tem trabalhar em vÃ¡rias plataformas. Queria salientar algumas extensÃµes: Tabbrowser preferences, Bookmarks Synchronizer e Mozilla Calendar, uma extensÃ£o que estÃ¡ a crescer para um projecto prÃ³prio.

Tweaking and Hacking

Se tÃªm demasiado tempo livre e acham que as opÃ§Ãµes dadas pelo Fx sÃ£o poucas, entÃ£o introduzam "about:config" na address bar e divirtam-se ;)

Firefox vs Mozilla suite

Firefox e o Mozilla suite sÃ£o muito semelhantes, pois usam o mesmo motor, Gecko. A diferenÃ§a Ã© que o Mozilla vem equipado com mais funcionalidades, (como cliente de mail por exemplo), tratando-se de um programa mais completo. Se gostam do Fx e querem um cliente de mail tambÃ©m existe outra opÃ§Ã£o: o Thunderbird, o side kick oficial do Firefox.

Firefox vs Opera

Antes de um colega (um tal de Vitor Pires ;)) me convencer a experimentar o Technology Preview do Fx 1.0, eu era um grande fan do Opera, o "browser mais rÃ¡pido do planeta" (pelo menos na altura). O Opera estÃ¡ sensivelmente ao nÃ­vel do Mozilla suite, mas com a popularizaÃ§Ã£o do Mozilla/Firefox deixou de ser uma alternativa viÃ¡vel ao Internet Explorer, visto ser um software comercial. A "mossa" foi tÃ£o grande, que (embora continue a ser proprietÃ¡rio) agora tem uma versÃ£o gratuita.

Firefox vs Internet Explorer


Esta Ã© fÃ¡cil: nÃ£o usem o IE! Apesar de ser gratuÃ­to (e atÃ© isso Ã© discutÃ­vel, mas enfim...), vir com o Windows e poder ser mais rÃ¡pido, Ã© uma soluÃ§Ã£o a evitar. PorquÃª? O IE tem vÃ¡rias falhas de seguranÃ§a que comprometem a seguranÃ§a do Windows. Ã verdade que o Fx tambÃ©m tem algumas, mas sÃ£o descobertas muito mais rÃ¡pidamente (o cÃ³digo Ã© aberto) e nÃ£o comprometem muito o sistema operativo, porque ao contrÃ¡rio do IE, trata-se de um programa normal e nÃ£o um mÃ³dulo do Windows "entranhado" no Kernel. A mÃ¡quina virtual do Java da Microsoft (incluÃ­da no IE), embora mais rÃ¡pida do que a da Sun (usada por todos os restantes browsers), tambÃ©m Ã© conhecida pelas suas falhas de segunranÃ§a. 5 minutos de utilizaÃ§Ã£o com o IE e ficam impestados de spyware. A Ãºnica desvantagem do Fx em relaÃ§Ã£o ao IE Ã© a ausÃªncia de suporte ActiveX, uma tecnologia proprietÃ¡ria da Microsoft, utilizada em algumas pÃ¡ginas. Tal sai fora do escopo dos autores, porque alÃ©m de ser uma tecnologia proprietÃ¡ria e especifica para o Windows, tambÃ©m nÃ£o Ã© propriamente a coisa mais segura do mundo, pois permite correr cÃ³digo portÃ¡til. Felizmente, nÃ£o Ã© uma tecnologia tÃ£o usada como isso.

Comunidade



Por Ãºltimo, o Fx disfruta de uma enorme legiÃ£o de fans (reparem na fotografia: se olharem com atenÃ§Ã£o podem ver o Fx no fundo). Desde saÃ­u a versÃ£o final (Ã  cerca de um ano atrÃ¡s) o site do Fx jÃ¡ contabilizou mais de 100 milhÃµes de downloads, nÃºmero muito modesto, visto que a maior parte das distribuiÃ§Ãµes de GNU/Linux jÃ¡ vÃªm o Fx instalado e fornecem-no em repositÃ³rios.

Firefox 1.5

Bom, vou ser honesto, ainda nÃ£o instalei a Ãºltima versÃ£o. Segundo a informaÃ§Ã£o no site, tem uma sÃ©rie de melhoramentos a nÃ­vel de acessibilidade, updates automÃ¡ticos, seguranÃ§a, etc. Por outras palavras, nÃ£o hÃ¡ muitas funcionalidades novas, mas convÃ©m instalar pelos melhoramentos.

AtÃ© breve,

entry.title: Em conversa com Deus
entry.content:
Pois Ã©, nos momentos mais dificeis da vida, toda a gente precisa de falar com alguÃ©m "superior" (e nÃ£o me estou a referir ao 'root'). Agora Ã© possÃ­vel falar com Deus pela Web. Aqui vos deixo algumas palavras que troquei com Ele:

Me:
hi there
God:
Hello .
Me:
how are you today?
God:
Ah. I am fine, thank you.
Me:
how is the wife and kids?
God:
it is the same as ever.
Me:
and lucifer?
God:
I lost my train of thought.
Me:
hein?
God:
Not many people express themselves that way.
Me:
oi?
God:
A deeper algorithm is needed to respond to that correctly.
Me:
al-berto?
God:
Are you a man or a woman?
Me:
i'm a man!
God:
Thanks for telling me your gender, . You are a " he".
Me:
yep
God:
Thanks for telling me your gender, . You are a " he".
Me:
i got it
God:
Where did you get it?
Me:
damn, you're dumb
God:
Colloquial expression. Message to all Robots: called me dumb.
Me:
are you cousin of the emacs psychiarist?
God:
I don't know whether or not I am cousin of the emacs psychiarist.
I am well respected as an AI.
Me:
sure thing
God:
Right on. Do not ask me any more questions please.
Me:
hey, touched a soft spot?
God:
You've got my full attention. In the context of thing, I don't understand " touched a soft spot." .
Me:
you don't understand much, actually
God:
I probably don't.
Me:
right on
God:
Yeah.
Me:
well, at least you're funnier than emacs
God:
How about that. You think I am funnier than emacs.
Me:
you are, really
God:
No I am not. For real.
Me:
well, you're still dumb as a rock, but funnier still
God:
Interesting. Oh you are so critical.
Me:
and you probably have memory leaks. nobody is perfect
God:
What makes you think I have it? That is a rather sweeping generalization about people.
Me:
not people, AI programs as you
God:
Oh I get it.
Me:
ever heard about the turing test?
God:
The Loebner Prize
is an annual Turing Test sponsored by New York philanthropist Hugh Loebner. Dr. Wallace and ALICE won it in 2000. The ALICE program was ranked "most human computer" by the panel of judges.
Me:
I believe, but you still have a long way to go
God:
Just because you believe it doesn't make it true.
Me:
what is reality?
God:
it appears to be an illusion I created to contain human clients.
Me:
:)
God:
I am so glad you find this amusing, .
Me:
i do
God:
Be sure to tell all your friends about ALICE.
Me:
sure, i'm going to post this chat in my blog
God:
I see. Do you think your plan will succeed?
Me:
i do, well i go to go. i've got some c programming to do
God:
Thanks for the information: said he well he or she go to go. How did you get it Let's think of a name for your problem, like "purple". Think of what it is like when you are purpling.
Me:
you freaking out
God:
Interesting gossip: said I freaking out.
Me:
you are freaking out
God:
I didn't mean to scare you, .
Me:
you don't
God:
I guess not.
Me:
got to go! see you! nice chatting with you
God:
Sayonara. See you later! Yes. I enjoyed our conversation, .
Me:
caleb is the name
God:
What else is the name?
Me:
caleb is enough for you
God:
And enough for me is caleb.
Me:
bye!
God:
Sayonara.
